Project MUSE Journals Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011 Kneaded Language: Concrete Poetry and New Media in the Swedish 1960s

Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

Kneaded Language:
Concrete Poetry and New Media in the Swedish 1960s
Jesper Olsson

In the early 1960s, Sweden witnessed the advent of a new type of poetic writing. It was a writing that deviated from the lyrical protocols of the time, a writing that did not seem to pay proper attention to poetry as a conveyor of metaphoric messages or as an instrument for excavating the depths of the human soul. Thus, in the fall of 1961, the artist and poet Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd, whose earlier work had gravitated towards Nonsense verse, Dada, and the practice of Marcel Duchamp, published a book called På samma gång (At the Same Time), consisting of words dislodged from a dictionary, distributed symmetrically across the page.1

Flowing Doll Cloth Position Manufacture
Difference Claim Best Laid Saffron
Crutch Grub Stamp Liqueur Fire
Mackerel Rubber Discord D-minor Module

Instead of creating semantically significant syntactic structures, Reuterswärd construed linguistic grids. Instead of stitching verbal elements together into a "living" tissue, he engineered a surface of signs, where each word constitutes an atomized and semantically multifunctional unit.

A few months before this book appeared, something similar took place in the new literary magazine Rondo. In its second issue, four texts were printed from a series of poems called "Hyllningarna" (The Celebrations) by the young poet and composer Bengt Emil Johnson.2 Johnson had earlier published a few poems situated within an established modernist poetics, while at the same time paying homage to the tradition of nature poetry in Sweden. His new work, however, moved in a somewhat different direction, partly due to his interest in contemporary music, and in particular the music of John Cage. In these poems language was processed beyond the confines of grammar, producing sound play and wild juxtapositions, forcing the reader to acknowledge "the word as such," in line with the credo of Russian futurism.

youi o-ing youing-you yokingyou ing mouthwet you
slumquarters into sings
:to-into under front :to-in-to-you to-ing-nt-in
gathering lovely to
:a mouth–to-park-o-ing drives waltz-o-tô

If Reuterswärd confronted language as something to be collected, sampled, and arranged, Johnson tested the possibility of shaping or molding words as if they were some kind of physical matter. What they had in common, however, was the focus on language as material, as something to construct and combine with, without the restraints of linguistic conventions or any notions of a "natural" language. Such deviations might certainly be considered endemic to poetry, but here they were pursued with an insistence and inclination towards artifice unprecedented in Swedish literature.

While some were bewildered by these experiments, others seemed more attuned to their workings. "A kind of concrete poetry," the critic Bengt Höglund suggested in his perceptive review of Reuterswärd in the leading literary journal in Sweden, Bonniers Litterära Magasin (BLM), at the same time reiterating comments issued earlier that year and confirming the arrival of a new genre.3 If the advent of concrete poetry in Sweden was thus announced, it was however an event marked by belatedness. Already in 1954, the poet and artist Öyvind Fahlström had declared the form's potentially prosperous future in his article "Hätila ragulpr på fåtskliaben" ("Hipy papy bthuthdth thuthda bthuthdy," a phrase culled from A. A. Milne's children's book Winnie the Pooh), where it was presented as a challenge to the self-expressivity and symbolism of a post-romantic modernism. With a voice framed by the generic conventions of the avant-garde manifesto, and with a quote from F. T. Marinetti as supporting epigraph, Fahlström thus claimed, "Today, with laboured symbolic cryptograms, silly romantic effusions or desperate grimaces outside the church gate being propounded as the only healthy options, the concrete alternative must also be presented."4

At that point in time, no one listened. But the times were changing. Seven years later, in an essay called "Bris" (Breeze), published in Rondo 3, 1961, Fahlström returned to his manifesto and to his "bord," as he called his concrete poems, using a portmanteau consisting of "bokstäver" and "ord" (words and letters).5 Now, against the backdrop of the new poetry and art that had emerged in an international context during the second half of the 1950s—Fahlström explicitly mentions concrete poetry from Brazil, Germany, Switzerland, and other places as well as artists and composers such as Cage and Robert Rauschenberg—he considered it urgent to once again address the possibility of a poetry not anchored in narrative, metaphor, and self-expression; a poetry open to formal and medial hybridization, to chance and procedural play, and to the exploration of the materiality of language as sound, visual conration, and, even, an object to touch.

However, Swedish concrete poetry was to deviate not only from the standard formats of poetry in its home environment. It would also, in part, distinguish itself from the dominant forms of concrete poetry that were disseminated globally during the 1950s and early 1960s, and thus challenge some narrower definitions of the genre.6 In this essay I will explore a few of these differences. But the main goal of the text is to map out the emergence of concrete poetry in Sweden, how its poetics of artifice were elaborated, and how it was fueled not only by its adherence to an avant-garde tradition in poetry, music, and art, but also by certain historical conditions that marked the postwar period—in particular its expanding ecology of new media. Concrete poetry's emergence during a threshold in the history of media, marked by the introduction of new technologies such as television, the tape recorder, and the computer, and new and radical theories of communication and information, such as cybernetics, is no coincidence. The postwar years might even be said to inaugurate a new "discourse network" (Friedrich A. Kittler), whose workings are difficult to trace—we are still immersed in it—but whose effects can be observed reverberating within the aesthetic practice that will be addressed here.7

I

The inception of concrete poetry in Sweden must then be dated to the publication of Öyvind Fahlström's article in the mimeo magazine Odyssé in the spring of 1954, where it was accompanied by the poem "MOA " (see excerpt, re 1). This text, which was later to be subtitled "Manifesto for Concrete Poetry," was at the outset a polemic against the conservatism of the contemporary poetry scene, but its main thrust was to be found in the outline of a poetics based on language as "concrete matter." Before publishing his manifesto, Fahlström had been trying for a few years to find a way as a writer. He was sitting on a pile of unpublished manuscripts indebted to the poetics of Surrealism, especially those strands that led to Antonin Artaud and to the erotic machinations of the proto-Surrealist Marquis de Sade.8 Evoking a certain corporeality and an interest in scatology and eroticism, the legacy of these writers was smuggled into his concretist poetics, and thus grafted a bodily materialism onto the linguistic materialism that was the focus of his manifesto—a bodily materialism that in the end would include all forms of physical matter.9

Fahlström's key ideas, posited in his manifesto, were to comprise a kind of toolbox for future concrete poets. While starting off with claiming that one can proceed intuitively or according to systematic principles (he mentions, for example, the methods of twelve-tone music), he soon begins to discuss a set of formal devices. These can be organized along three vectors, similar to the tripartition of poetry by Ezra Pound into phanopoeia, melopoeia, and logopoeia, and to the analysis of the linguistic sign as a "verbivocovisual" entity, as suggested by James Joyce, and, later, the Noigandres poets in Brazil (i.e. Augusto and Harold de Campos and Décio Pignatari). Firstly, Fahlström emphasizes the exploration of the visual space of the page, for example through alternative stanza formations and vertical spacing of letters and words, the aim being to liberate the reader's gaze from its linear and lateral programs. Secondly, he draws attention to the dynamics of rhythm and res of sound. And thirdly, most importantly, Fahlström suggests that one should approach language as physical matter, as a tactile object that one can squeeze and manipulate.


Click for larger view
1. 

From Öyvind Fahlström, "MOA ", early version published in the mimeo magazine Odyssé 2–3, 1954.

© 2011 Sharon Avery-Fahlström. Reprinted with kind permission from Sharon Avery-Fahlström, The Öyvind Fahlström Foundation and Archives at MACBA

KNEAD the linguistic material; this is what justifies the label concrete. Don't just manipulate the whole structure; begin rather with the smallest elements—letters, words. Recast the letters as in anagrams. Repeat letters within words; throw in alien words, plea–vroog–se–do; interpose letters that don't belong, aacatioaanniya for action; explore children's secret code languages and other private languages; vocal glides: gliaouedly. And, of course, newly coined lettristic words. Abbreviation—on a manic scale—to coin new words, as in everyday language [ … ].10

Through cuts and incisions into the very texture of signs, through substitutions, inversions, and interventions into the laws of word formation and syntax, the significance of the poetic text is programmatically displaced and shifted from the hermeneutic logic of surface writing and depth meaning, manifest media and latent message towards a play with material signifiers.11

Fahlström was of course aware of a line of predecessors to his "concrete alternative." He mentions writers from "the Greeks" to Rabelais, from Lewis Carroll to Gertrude Stein, Kurt Schwitters, Artaud, and Lettrism.12 One visual artist is also cited, the Italian painter Giuseppe Capogrossi, but symptomatically—it was probably too purist in its outlook—not much credence is given to concrete art. Music, on the other hand, and especially the musique concrète of French composer Pierre Schaeffer, stands out as emblematic for the poetics that Fahlström wants to expound. "If I use the word concrete in this context it is thus more in relation to concrete music than to concrete art in a restricted sense," he declares, and explicates further:

The fundamental principle of concrete poetry is perhaps most beautifully illustrated by Pierre Schaeffer's experience during his search for concrete music: he had on tape a few seconds of railway engine sound, but was not content just to follow that sound with another, even where the juxtaposition was itself unusual. Instead, he cut out a small fragment of the engine sound and repeated this fragment at a slightly different pitch; then went back to the first, then the second, and so on, setting up an alternation. Only then had he actually created; he had operated on the material itself by cutting it up, the elements were not new; but from the new context thereby created emerged new matter.13

In addition to influences from literature and art, the concrete alternative thus finds support in an innovative musical practice. But beyond this cluster of intra-aesthetic impulses something else is disclosed. Schaeffer's musique concrète was historically dependent on technical inventions in the realms of sound recording—without the latter the former would not exist. As Liz Kotz has suggested in a recent study, sound recording, and more specifically the tape recorder, can actually be seen as an important, if not determining instance for a wide range of innovative language based art in the 1960s.14 Kotz's focus is on the American situation, and her main artistic reference is John Cage. In a Swedish context one might substitute Cage with Schaeffer, and considering the latter's prominent position in Fahlström's poetics, it is necessary to stress the role of magnetic recording in relation to Swedish concrete poetry.

Magnetic recording separates sounds and voices from their sources in time and space, and turns them into objects to manipulate—through technical operations such as cut'n'splice, erasure, superimposition, and so on. And, crucially, this is the operative register that Fahlström transposes to the media of language and poetry. Poetry is weaned from its aesthetic roots in the human voice and mind, and the process is relayed through the machinery of a new media technology as well as through an avant-garde aesthetics. While concrete poetry, to a certain extent, repeats forms, methods, and gestures from the early avant-garde of futurism and dada, these are not only theoretically refined through a more sophisticated "analysis" of the linguistic sign, they are also activated in a new historical and technological situation, which widens and differentiates their significance. The materialization of language in concrete poetry could thus be said both to reflect and comment upon a cultural situation in which, for example, voice was not the identifying mark of an individual or a human body, but an acoustic effect open for technological manipulation and distribution.

II

Around 1960, Öyvind Fahlström's manifesto began to circulate in Xeroxed copies among younger poets in Sweden.15 Together with his poetry, and his essay "Bris", it would play an essential role in the formation of a specifically Swedish tradition of concrete poetry. Even if not constituting a movement in a strict sense, the work of writers and artists such as Mats G. Bengtsson, Torsten Ekbom, Elis Eriksson, Jarl Hammarberg, Åke Hodell, Bengt Emil Johnson, Leif Nylén, and Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd, would at least establish a network of aesthetic (and often social) relations, connected to magazines such as Rondo and Gorilla, and to venues such as Fylkingen and Moderna Museet in Stockholm.16 The term "concrete poetry" also occupied a central position in the debates about open form and the hybridization of the arts during the first half of the 1960s. In contrast to the situation in most other countries, concrete poetry in Sweden was not only presented and discussed in little magazines and similar contexts, but also in the big media.17 Most collections of concrete poetry were—with some exceptions, such as Åke Hodell's small press Kerberos—published by the country's largest publishing house, Bonniers. This specific infrastructure definitely contributed to the genre's breakthrough, but the lack of alternative institutional structures might also have been one of the causes for its rather quick disappearance from the literary field towards the end of the decade.18

Tracing the effects of Fahlström's ideas simplifies the task of mapping concrete poetry in Sweden. A key operation was, as indicated above, the "kneading" of language, a process that should begin at the lowest levels of poetry. Here numbers, graphemes, diacritical signs, code, and so on, would infiltrate the alphabet. A paradigmatic example of this mixture of sign systems is Jarl Hammarberg's rendering, in a poem, of "question mark" as "fr?g?tck?n," where three of the vowels in the word have been substituted by the mark in question.19 Such an ironic intervention into the word highlights the artifice of concrete poetry, but it also points out the wider field of signification that it was to investigate, such as the relationship between symbolic, iconic, and indexical signs. In some productions of Swedish concrete, alphabetic signs were even to be excluded completely. In Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd's infamous book Prix Nobel (re 2), a work published in 1966, but initiated in the beginning of the decade, one encounters a web of punctuation marks spread out over the pages, orchestrating an absent text or speech.20

The poem, which in part anticipates verbal operations in conceptual art, suggests an open work, a score, for which the reader must provide not only voice, but also words. Spacing here comes forward as the primary condition for poetry, and perhaps there is a poetic process at play already in these diagrammatic grids, these fragile framings of a supposedly absent content. When Reuterswärd made a sound recording of his poem in 1963, he subverted the idea of an absent content as well as the well-known hermeneutical expectations of filling the lacunae of a text. All that was heard from the grooves in the record was an ironic voice articulating "comma, comma, dash … "21


Click for larger view
2. 

Excerpt from Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd, Prix Nobel (Stockholm: Bonniers, 1966).

The most conspicuous effects of this manipulative poetics would, however, surface on the level of word formation and syntax. In the same manner as elsewhere on the globe of concrete poetry, different kinds of transformations and displacements of letters were effectuated, and syntactical organization would be substituted with lists, series, grids, permutations, and clusters. A discernible difference in Swedish concrete, particularly if compared with the output of influential work by Eugen Gomringer in Switzerland or the Brazilian Noigandres poets during the "heroic phase" of concrete poetry in the late 1950s, was that these operations were often mixed with other methods, and they were not always used in a consistent manner; they were rather heuristic devices in the field of poetic research than prescriptive models to follow. One should of course be wary of constructing a monolith either of Swedish concrete poetry or its others, but where Gomringer's or the early Noigandres' works strove for brevity, balance, and isomorphism in the "verbivocovisual" complex of the linguistic sign, the poems in Sweden often tended to be longer, formally heterogeneous, and perforated by representational elements as well as semantic excess and graphic and acoustic noise.22

One reason for this can be traced to its surrealist legacy, a legacy that was denounced by several other concrete poets, for example Haroldo de Campos.23 This legacy also explains the exploration of scatological, alimentary, sexual, and dreamlike imagery in a lot of Swedish concrete, which contrasts starkly with the formal constraints and mechanical procedures of the poetry, while at the same time establishing a productive tension between human and machine, nature and artifice. The combinatorial play with letters and words would result in unsettling verbal aggregates such as "leatherbrain" or "siphonenvirons" (Bengt Emil Johnson), disclosing a grotesque, if not cybernetic, anatomy of alien bodies, "out of which pencils grow," to employ an image from Jarl Hammarberg, which evokes the influential notion of media as extensions of man in an even more tangible way than in the media anthropology of Marshall McLuhan.

Another reason for the Swedish specificities is to be found in the readiness to combine systematic formal procedures with "intuitive" or "subjective" operations. Contemporary Swedish critics also tried to make a distinction between the homegrown version of concrete and its German namesake, for example, by describing the former as more subjective, romantic, organic, and handwritten.24 If this indicates a difference, it is, however, a difference in degree. Moreover, it might even be misleading when situating Swedish concrete within the larger field of poetic writing. I would rather claim that the binaries evoked here—subjective/objective, natural/artificial, expressive/constructive, organic/mechanic—binaries often used to describe, interpret, and evaluate poetry—are destabilized and challenged in this poetic project.

Some of this can be observed in the work of Bengt Emil Johnson. Johnson's concrete poetry was on the one hand charged by an interest in the procedures of contemporary (e.g. serial) music, on the other hand it was nourished by a verbal imagination indebted to burlesque, surrealist, and even romantic poetic imagery. In his first collection, Hyllningarna (The Celebrations), one finds, for example, the poem "Fyra bluestexter" (Four Blues Lyrics), which, apart from alluding to Blues, employs a compositional method analogous to those in serial music. Here are the first two unrhymed couplets in the first of the poem's four sections (rendered in Swedish):25

man har fog för sin gråsot du nu har nog närdröms ventilsystem fel
vart hon rör sig går hon mjukrundat mot väggförgrening gnyende svagt

och för sitt vågblods skull mutation när höstbensin ryker ner medarna
för i år och nu blundar hon självsökande i tystheten sakta tom

Johnson's poem is constructed according to a strict rule—every line must employ the same set of eighteen vowels (aaoöiåouuaoäöeiyee), with the adjunct that the first vowel in each line is displaced to the last position in the following line, thus producing a cyclic movement in the poem's sound pattern. Even if not a chance procedure in the manner of Cage, the poem is partly generated by this external constraint, and it is marked by a semantic indeterminacy. Some of the poem's syntactical oddities and coinages—"närdröms" (closedream's), "vågblods" (waveblood's) and "höstbensin" (autumngasoline)—can be attributed to this constraint or rule. But, at the same time, the poem's vocabulary is distinctly Johnsonian, as if the rule was from the beginning in sync with the poet's material and metaphoric imagination. The result is a strange mix of programmatic constraint and poetic license, objective restriction and subjective intervention, also discernible elsewhere in Johnson's work.

III

The kneading operations employed in Swedish concrete were certainly not limited to letters, words, and syntax. They were also integral or at least connected to the other two methods in Fahlström's manifesto—the exploration of visuality and sonority. These methods of materializing poetry would also pave the way for a transgression of the book as the privileged media technology of poetry. The significance of sound recording was, as we saw, possible to perceive already in Fahlström's manifesto, and the conceptual proximity between concrete poetry and visual art led to an investigation of new materials and alternative venues for the presentation of poems, such as the gallery space.

One link between concrete poetry and sound was, as we have seen, forged through Fahlström's interest in musique concrète. This relationship was at the core of his poetics, and it resulted in a transposition of methods and models between the two arts and the inclination to apply concepts from music in poetic writing. If this is something of a perennial maneuver in poetry, the tendency to entitle poems sonatas or quartets and similar things was here expanded to include, for example, reading instructions. Some poems were also composed explicitly as scores for a performance, such as Fahlström's "Den svåra resan" (The Difficult Journey) from the mid-1950s, which had the significant subtitle "For Mixed Speech Choir," and which was organized as a set of notations for eighteen different voices (re 3).26

Such sign/sound amalgamations reach over into the realm of sound poetry, and it is difficult, if not counterproductive, to establish a generic demarcation line here. Swedish concrete poets often used res such as alliteration and assonance in an excessive way, and the kneading of letters and words makes accessible a latent acoustic space within language, either through alphabetic notations of sound, or through actual vocalizations of everything from song to soundscapes on stage, record, and tape. Several publications of concrete poetry were, consequently, supplemented either with a recording or a stage performance, such as Åke Hodell's first book of concrete poetry igevär (Shoulder Arms, 1963), a minimalist satire of the military-industrial complex, consisting of a single utterance ("iiiiiiiiiiii … gev … äääää … r"), graphically extended to fill the pages of a whole book, and vocally rendered in a long and strenuous performance with six readers.27 On the whole, this performative aspect was integral to the practice, and resulted in tumultuous tours of concrete poetry through Sweden and the other Nordic countries during the years 1963–1964.

Even more acoustically elaborated was the development of concretist methods in the sound recording studio. This possibility was acutely present for many Swedish poets, who collaborated with engineers at Sveriges Radio (Swedish Public Radio) to explore the aesthetic potential of sound. The recordings of concrete poems, enhanced and refined through echo, filtering, and backward playback, would further evolve into work with sound collage, and eventually lead to the birth of the genre of text-sound composition.28 Crucial in this process were the radio pieces by Fahlström, not the least his pioneer "radiophonic poem" Fåglar i Sverige (Birds in Sweden, 1962), which combined operations from concrete poetry with narrative and juxtapositions of a variety of recorded sounds (opera, pop music, machine guns, elephants).29 This was certainly poetry based on the presence of sound recording technology. As Bengt Emil Johnson and the composer Lars Gunnar Bodin wrote in 1964: "Tape recorders, contact microphones and sophisticated loud speaker systems, projectors etcetera are instruments that through their sheer existence change the conditions for artistic work."30 Poetry was on the verge of leaving the Gutenberg Galaxy—a tendency that would also affect the poetic production that was still to be registered in print.


Click for larger view
3. 

Excerpt from Öyvind Fahlström, "Den svåra resan", published in Bord Dikter 1952–1955 (Stockholm: Bonniers, 1966), 43.

© 2011 Sharon Avery-Fahlström. Reprinted with kind permission from Sharon Avery-Fahlström, The Öyvind Fahlström Foundation and Archives at MACBA

The visually more conspicuous works of concrete poetry, however, mostly emerged in print, between the tarnished covers of the book, even though sometimes transposed to a life between frames, as in the big manifestation and exhibition of concrete poetry Svisch at Moderna Museet in 1964.31 The visual imagination and methodology in Swedish concrete poetry was as vivid and various as its "tactile" and acoustic counterparts. It ranged from typewriter graphics and typographic variations to handwritten poems, drawings, and collage. While poets such as Jarl Hammarberg and Mats G. Bengtsson investigated handwriting in poems that could be related both to comic strips and to the scripts of art brut, Åke Hodell, for example, explored the potential of the collage in a series of books from the period. Most convincing is perhaps his Självbiografi (Autobiography, 1967) (re 4), where the title suggests a specific generic status, and thus a certain form, but where the reader encounters not a chronological narrative of the poet's life, but a montage of texts from Plato, Marx, Nietzsche, and others, juxtaposed with photographs from Eadwaerd Muybridge, military maps, comics, diagrams, and so on. The techniques used to construct this autobiography—and this is an interpretation that finds support in other works by Hodell—suggest that human identity as such is to be considered a montage, or a constantly shifting aggregate of body, mind, and various representations generated from different media machines.32


Click for larger view
4. 

From Åke Hodell, Självbiografi (Stockholm: Rabén & Sjögren, 1967).

The use of the typewriter as an excavator of verbivisual space—a privileged method in concrete poetry in general—was perhaps most dynamically realized in Bengt Emil Johnson's second book, Essäer om Bror Barsk och andra dikter (Essays on Brother Rough and Other Poems, 1964) (re 5). Generically unstable, just as Hodell's book, this collection also testifies to the mix of organic and mechanic elements that was touched upon before.33 But, first and foremost, Johnson's book exploits the combinatorial possibilities of the verbal and the visual within concrete poetry. In his essay "Bris," Fahlström had discussed the typewriter as an instrument for poetry, and among other things he touched upon its role in constructing "word maps," a designation that fits well with the linguistic landscapes in Johnson's book.34 This is a poetry that urges the reader to wander around on a surface—or in a space, since the layering of words sometimes evokes illusions of depth. Further, to discern the visual res on the pages, or to read the words and sentences in Johnson's book, one has to change the distance to the actual object and even turn it around. The physical motor activity of the reader is thus more varied than the one usually accompanying readings of poetry. One might conceive of this book as a proto-cybertext or as an ergodic piece of literature, to use the terminology Espen Aarseth has established in his influential theory of digital texts.35 Even though cybernetics, as the new theory of communication during the 1960s—and it would have an obvious impact on avant-garde writing in Sweden—is comically degraded in Johnson's book ("new wanking grammar"), this is a book that embraces and explores the new media conditions of poetry, while at the same time challenging their determining and regulating force on perception, understanding, and conceptualization.


Click for larger view
5. 

From Bengt Emil Johnson, Essäer om Bror Barsk och andra dikter (Stockholm: Bonniers, 1964).

IV

Essäer om Bror Barsk thus actualizes something that has been of vital concern here—concrete poetry as a poetry "in the age of media". While Swedish concrete poetry explicitly tied onto an avant-garde tradition of writing—most directly addressed, perhaps, by Fahlström in his references to Stein, Artaud, Schwitters, and others in the manifesto—there were also other factors that shaped its forms, methods, and medial materializations. Within the restricted field of aesthetic practice, music perhaps served as a primary model, even more so than literature. But the negotiation with the new media ecology of the postwar period was an equally important aspect. In Fahlström's poetics, the impact of the advent of technical sound recording was integral to the development of linguistic kneading and Schaeffer's manipulated recordings offered a contemporary frame of reference for his poetics. In Åke Hodell's poetry, modern technology was frequently evoked as formative for human identity and experience—and, of course, for reading and writing—while also being criticized for its potentially dehumanizing effects. And in Bengt Emil Johnson's work, new music and its reliance on technical sound recording would give the impulse to an imaginative use of technology, poetic constraints, and media based protocols, which were also to be challenged in radical ways, for example, as we saw, by turning the logic and the expected output of a typewriter inside out—typing a text whose signs don't come forward in a discrete series, but overlaid and blurred, by neglecting the lateral-linear spacing for a more tumultuous graphic space, by approaching illegibility instead of legibility, and so on.

Such features make it easy to juxtapose Swedish concrete poetry with a set of other innovative artistic practices during the 1960s, such as musique concrète, Fluxus, happenings, and conceptual art. The mutual reliance on new media led to similar formal, material, and methodological solutions, which sometimes becomes obvious, for example, in the case of a poet and artist such as Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd, whose work, retrospectively, might just as well be categorized as conceptual art or writing. On the other hand, as several critics have suggested in recent years, concrete poetry (also the Swedish branch) seems to anticipate the digital textuality that has been explored during the last decades. Non-linearity, hypertextuality, multimediality, and post-alphabetic writing are all characteristics that can be used to describe the "concretist" practice. Moreover, the interest in cybernetics and code, and the investigation of rule-based poems, disclose an "algorithmic imagination" at play that underpins such a comparison.

From the horizon of the present, (digital) media conditions might actually help us to re-frame and re-conceptualize some of these avant-garde works from the 1960s.36 But, vice versa, the concretist works can also give us a perspective on some of the historical and material conditions for the contemporary web of digital media, a web whose effects sometimes seem so exhilarating and sublime that its material and historical foundations tend to be erased. Such an observation offers a clue to the renewed interest in recent years in concrete poetry, not the least among contemporary poets. It is perhaps not only that the "multimedium" of the computer opens up a new space for exploring poetry as a verbivocovisual endeavour; concrete poetry might also offer tools (even if re-formatted for a present situation) to question and complicate the features and forms of culture and media today.

Jesper Olsson  

Jesper Olsson is a Swedish Academy researcher at the Department of Literature and the History of Ideas, Stockholm University. In 2005 he published a comprehensive study of Swedish concrete poetry and is currently writing a book on audiotape and the tape recorder in postwar literature and art.

Project MUSE Journals Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011 Modernist Networks: Taxco, 1931

Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

Modernist Networks:
Taxco, 1931
A. Joan Saab

In a 1931 photograph entitled "Meeting in Taxco during Siqueiros's house arrest," the Mexican artist David Alfaro Siqueiros sits between the American architect and silver impresario William Spratling and the Russian avant-garde filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein; the Mexican filmmaker Chano Ureta is seated next to Eisenstein [re 1]. As the title suggests, at the time of the photo Siqueiros had been recently exiled to Taxco, a small mining town approximately one hundred miles southwest of Mexico City, after spending eight months in a Mexico City prison for "subversive activities." In Taxco, the artist lived in an abandoned church high above the city which also housed his workshop as well as a gallery, an art school for children, and a meeting place for the newly emerging artistic and intellectual community which recently began traveling to Taxco to buy the silver produced in Spratling's workshop.

What does the meeting of three international modernists in a small Mexican town in 1931 tell us about early 20th-century global networks—both real and imagined? In the image, all four men wear hats and look directly at the camera. Their choice of headwear is illuminating. Spratling and Siqueiros wear leather sombreros popular among vaqueros (Mexican cowboys) and revolutionaries, Eisenstein and Ureta wear berets, which in 1931 were already a symbol of the Parisian bohemian artist. While their choices may not be intentionally provocative, through objects as benign as hats, the men signify multiple cultural allegiances. Siqueiros' and Spratling's sombreros evoke vernacular Mexican traditions while Eisenstein and Ureta's berets place them within a more cosmopolitan milieu. Thus this image demonstrates how material goods can signify meaning; it also speaks directly to the tensions between the local and the universal that frame the history of global modernism. This article explores these tensions by focusing on the real and imagined networks that linked these artists at this particular moment in time.1 By focusing on the multiple networks that brought Siqueiros, Spratling, and Eisenstein to Taxco in 1931—chains of interconnected people, ideas, and things—I hope to bridge the universal and the local, the national and the cosmopolitan, the folk and the modern to reach across oceans, time periods, and mediums to complicate our understanding of global modernism. In particular, I pay attention to the centrality of new forms of technology and material goods to chart the creation and proliferation of a vernacular modernist vocabulary.


Click for larger view
1. 

Meeting in Taxco during Siqueiros's house arrest Col. INBA - Sala de Arte Público Siqueiros Reproducción autorizada por el Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes y Literatura, 2010.

I am borrowing the term vernacular modernism from the film scholar Miriam Hansen. While she uses it to discuss the idea of Americanism in classical Hollywood film in the context of Soviet avant-garde cinema, I think the concept is helpful here since it both articulates and mediates the experience of modernity, "such as mass produced and mass consumed phenomenon of fashion, design, advertising, architecture and urban environment, of photography, radio and cinema."2 The idea of a mass-produced vernacular, as opposed to the popular (which in the Mexican example has a different meaning than it does in the United States; it is more closely aligned with what we call the folk), highlights the place of the quotidian and the local within universalizing discourses of modernism and modernity. Within vernacular modernism, the marketplace becomes a crucial site for the dissemination of what it means to be modern at this moment in time. 3

By 1931 Mexico was already a hub in the modernist network, both real and imagined. Indeed, American art historians often refer to the late 1920s through the early 1940s as the years of the "Mexican craze" or the "Mexican Invasion."4 Due in part to the wars in Europe as well as to increased railway travel between the Americas, Mexico became a popular tourist destination. Anthropologist Nestor Garcia Canclini, in his study of Latin American modernism, stresses the importance of tourism in creating internal national as well as international cultural identities. He compellingly argues that one of the enduring effects of the tourist market is to turn the particularities of ethnic cultural expression into a larger category of "type."5 Indeed, as Alex Saragoza has pointed out, the post-revolutionary Mexican government capitalized on its tourist market to promote an intensely nationalist cultural project as a form of state building.6 Mexican restaurant owners, merchants, and hoteliers developed an essentialized vocabulary of national identity: lo mexicano, mexicanidad, el pueblo mexicano, etc—through which they created stock characters and images of the "typical Mexican garb, souvenirs, music, architecture" [re 2].7 The circulation of images was key to the success of this project. Posters such re 2, depicting a beautiful smiling woman carrying colorful fruit, surrounded by lush vegetation inhabited by exotic birds and flowers, enticed visitors to "Visit Mexico." The features of the woman in the image are not overly exoticized. The details of the landscape, with its palm trees and colorful parrots, but especially the women's long braids and tan skin as well as her dress—which is embellished with a pre-Columbian motif—mark her as different, but not too different.

Moreover, Mexican artists, in particular Los Tres Grandes, the big three muralists Diego Rivera, Jose Clemente Orozco, and David Alfaro Siqueiros, capitalized on their status as art world celebrities and their embrace of mexicanidad to secure lucrative commissions abroad. A number of exhibitions celebrating Mexico's pre-Columbian heritage, its folk arts, and its recent artistic renaissance were assembled and traveled throughout the United States.8 A number of artists and writers, including Katherine Ann Porter, Hart Crane, Martha Graham, Paul Strand, Marsden Hartley, Edward Weston, and John Dos Passos, to name just a few, traveled extensively or lived in Mexico during this period, and Hollywood producers promoted the exotic and revolutionary flavor of the country through films such as Girl of the Rio, Viva Villa , Bordertown (1935), and Juarez . These artists and exhibitions merged high and low culture, fine and folk art, pre-Columbian, colonial, and contemporary artifacts into a unified visual language of brightly colored images and objects as a means of signifying "Mexico." Through hand-woven serapes, elaborately ornate silver platters and jewelry, brightly painted handcrafted furniture, masks, and retablos, and paintings and photographs of beautiful and exotic natives, lush plant life, active volcanoes and prehistoric ruins, they created a recognizable Mexican iconography in the national and international imagination. Rather than go through a laundry list of events, artists, and visual tropes that constituted the Mexican craze, however, I want to look at the transnational marketplace of goods and ideas—the modernist network—that brought Eisenstein, Spratling, and Siqueiros to Taxco in 1931.


Click for larger view
2. 

Visit Mexico Poster. Collection of the author.

How did a radical modern painter like Siqueiros, the avant-garde Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein, and William Spratling, known as the "Silver Gringo," end up posing for this photo in the small silver mining town of Taxco? Located in the hills between Acapulco and Mexico City in the state of Guerrero, Taxco was a three-day burro ride from Mexico City until 1930 when the Mexican government built a highway connecting the town to the capital as part of a campaign to physically unify the nation and to allow for increased international tourism in the area. Taxco is one of the oldest mining sites in the Americas. When Hernan Cortez conquered the Aztecs in 1521, he lay stake to the mines and by the end of the century, Taxco was Spain's primary source for silver. During the 19th-century War for Independence, however, many Spanish barons destroyed their mines rather than lose them to "revolutionaries." Silver production in Taxco went into decline for over one hundred years. In 1931 William Spratling brokered a mural by Diego Rivera for his friend Dwight Morrow, the U.S. ambassador to Mexico. He used the money he received as a commission to open a silver workshop. Spratling almost single-handedly resuscitated the silver industry in Taxco by teaching the local inhabitants how to produce silver jewelry and decorative objects the way their ancestors did. He imported a master teacher and incorporated pre-Columbian motifs into his work, which he sold in Taxco as well as in high-end U.S. department stores such as Neiman-Marcus, Bonwit Teller, and Saks Fifth Avenue. Yet Spratling's claims to vernacular tradition and native authenticity were mediated by his interest in modern technology—he did use contemporary machinery—and bore the marks of his background in modern architecture and design, particularly the Bauhaus.

Spratling was part of multiple modernist networks before he came to Mexico. Born in upstate New York in 1900, he moved to New Orleans to teach in the architecture program at Tulane after attending Auburn University. In New Orleans, Spratling lived in the French Quarter where he quickly became part of the bohemian circle that centered around the author Sherwood Anderson. According to his landlord Natalie Scott, he gave parties almost every night with "an easy efficiency that puts many hostesses to shame." He served absinthe, which he bought in great jugs from the widow of a bootlegger, and homemade gin, which he aerated in his attic. 9 In 1925 William Faulkner moved to New Orleans and rented one of the rooms in Spratling's apartment. By Faulkner's own account they were "drinking and carousing partners" and Spratling shows up as a character in a number of Faulkner's early works: in particular Soldier's Pay and the short story "Mosquitoes." The two men traveled together to Europe, where Spratling wrote articles on both classical and modern architecture for Scribner's magazine, the Journal of the American Institute of Architects, the Architecture Record, and many other architecture and travel publications. In 1926, back in New Orleans, they collaborated on the book Sherwood Anderson and Other Famous Creoles.

In 1926 Spratling visited Mexico for the first time. He returned for summers over the next several years, and in 1929, following "an unfortunate incident" with a male undergraduate at Tulane, which may or may not have led to a nervous breakdown, he moved to Mexico permanently.10 Settling first in Mexico City, he worked as a correspondent for the Herald Tribune writing a regular "Letter from Mexico" describing the City's colorful artistic scene for the paper's monthly book review. He was quickly introduced to and became a welcome participant in the artistic circles of Mexico. He became friends with Diego Rivera and his wife Frida Kahlo; the illustrator Miguel Covarrubias; as well as with the U.S. expatriates Francis Toor, the publisher with Diego Rivera of the bilingual journal Mexican Folkways; Dwight Morrow, the U.S. Ambassador to Mexico, and his wife, Elizabeth Cutler Morrow; and Frederick Davis, the proprietor of the Sonoma News Company, an emporium of things Mexican. 11

Late in 1929, Spratling moved to the hill town of Taxco. In his book, Little Mexico, Spratling described Taxco as "a place where each house is shining and compact, a study in red and white and green … yet the whole has that same unity of growth which exists in plants. For this reason people like to refer to it as picturesque."12 Ambassador Morrow and his wife Elizabeth were regular guests of Spratling in Taxco. Morrow, a classmate of Calvin Coolidge's at Amherst College, was a successful banker at JP Morgan before he became the US Ambassador to Mexico in 1927. Although he initially questioned his appointment to Mexico, he soon embraced the country and its culture. In an act of what might be called cultural diplomacy, the Morrows filled their house in the suburb of Cuernavaca, which they called Casa Manana, with Mexican art and furniture. Elizabeth Morrow recalled, "We furnished our little house entirely with Mexican things."13 Spratling assisted them in this endeavor. As a further act of cultural diplomacy, Morrow wished to give something to the people of Cuernavaca. In 1931, Spratling negotiated a deal between the Morrows and Rivera to paint a mural in the Palacio de Cortés, now the Museo Regional de Historia de Cuauhnahuac (Historical Museum of Cuauhnahuac). Spratling was paid a hefty commission for brokering the deal and he used this money as a down payment for a house and silver workshop in Taxco.

According to Spratling's memoir, one day over breakfast, Morrow said to him, "What a pity, Bill, that of all the tons of silver sent back from Taxco to the old world over the centuries, that none of this ever stayed here nor was utilized to create an industry or an economy for Taxco." 14 Subsequently, Spratling hired an experienced goldsmith from Iguala who moved to Taxco and began creating silver jewelry of Spratling's design. Other craftsmen joined Spratling's shop and began producing tin ware, copper items, textiles, and furniture - all designed by Spratling. These earliest designs were based on pre-Columbian motifs as well as simple themes: rope borders, strap designs and other basic forms. Much of Spratling's early work was influenced by Mexican pottery. He wrote: "The work of these Mexican potters not only satisfies rudimentary human needs; in its expression of the impulse to form beautiful things with the hands it also satisfies an ancient tradition of craftsmanship.… The interesting thing is that it remains with them as a living and fecund art."15

The idea that Mexicans had an innate ability to produce beautiful things was widespread at this time. For example, U.S. novelist Susan Smith wrote in her 1930 best-selling book, Made in Mexico, that, "in Mexico art isn't something that is kept in museums and spoken of only by critics. It is part of everyday life … Mexicans make beautiful things as a matter of course. They don't know how to make anything ugly."16 Spratling shared this romanticized attitude toward his Mexican workers. In a 1934 interview with the New Orleans Times Picayune, he explained his endeavor:

We can teach [the Indians] nothing in the way of handicraft or artistry. The only thing I have done is to capitalize this gift.… Instead of leaving all this precious metal and graceful workmanship to lie around loose, I persuade them to come into a shop. At least you might call it a shop. It is really just my house. And when I suggested to them that they might work eight hours a day and I would pay them from two to four pesos for their labor they seized on the idea with enthusiasm. Indians aren't so different from the rest of us. The idea of a steady salary looks good to them too.17

Late in 1931, the Mexican government built a highway between Mexico City and Taxco and the town became a major tourist destination—particularly for wealthy Mexicans and expatriates and tourists from Europe and the United States. Spratling's workshop and gallery became a regular stop on the tour. Other artisans soon set up shop in Taxco as well. For example, Elizabeth Anderson, the former wife of Sherwood Anderson, and a close friend of Spratling—she lived in an apartment in his house—began teaching the women of Taxco to embroider in their "native fashion." Her designs were quite successful and sold in the United States at places like Bloomingdale's. Spratling's pieces also sold in stores and catalogs across the United States as well as in Mexico. To both Mexicans and tourists, he affectionately became known as "the Silver Gringo." Years later, Rene d' Harnoncourt, who became the Director of MoMA and General Manager of the Indian Arts and Crafts Board, said of Spratling: "I know of no other person who has so deeply influenced the artistic orientation of a country that is not his own. Not only did Mr. Spratling's establishment of a studio-workshop in Taxco cause a true renaissance of Mexican traditional folk art in modern context, but his activities on behalf of the arts of Mexico, modern and ancient, created a climate of understanding which contributed greatly to their appreciation and acceptance."18

The irony of the "Silver Gringo" almost single-handedly reinvigorating the silver industry in Mexico is striking and points to a complex form of transnational modernism, one like a network that goes beyond nationality and citizenship. Spratling's silver designs became emblems of Mexican nationalism both inside and outside of Mexico. Frida Kahlo and other well-known proponents of mexicanidad regularly wore his pieces as emblems of national pride. And while he certainly employed pre-Columbian motifs, many of them were inspired by chinaware brought to Mexico by Spanish colonial settlers. Moreover, Spratling repeatedly integrated current fashions and modernist forms into his work. His work directly evokes the work of European jewelry makers such as George Jensen in its rounded lines and simple embellishments. Spratling was very interested in Bauhaus architecture and you can clearly see this in many of the goods he manufactured throughout the 1930s and 1940s. In a set of his cigarette boxes, for example, you can see the application of pre-Columbian motifs on stylized, modernistinspired consumer products. Moreover, a number of his trays and cocktail shakers are decidedly more Art Deco in their inspiration than pre-Columbian.

Spratling was an active participant in multiple artistic circles. He was friends with Faulkner and Anderson, Siqueiros and Rivera. The international artistic networks in which he moved are crucial for understanding the importance of the international marketplace in the creation of vernacular modernism. These networks and their circulation of goods and ideas did not move in one direction; rather, there was a regular back and forth across national borders, artistic mediums, and political ideologies—as we shall see in the case of both Eisenstein and Siqueiros, who were also part of this Mexican modernist network.

Eisenstein was part of an imagined Mexican network before he ever stepped foot in the country. Long before he came to Mexico, he imagined the country as a brightlycolored abstract tableau punctuated with serapes, saguaro, and sombreros. According to Inga Karetnikova, "in the life of Sergei Eisenstein, there was not one, but three Mexicos," the imaginary, the real, and the Mexico of memory.19 Indeed, Eisenstein's first theatrical project as a student at the Petrograd Institute of Civil Engineering was to design the sets and costumes for a play based on Jack London's short story, The Mexican. His set consisted of a spare modernist backdrop dotted with bright patches of color and scattered sombreros to signify "Mexico." But the biggest influence on Eisenstein's imagined Mexico were the epic murals of Diego Rivera, which told the history of Mexican conquest and revolution in visual form. Combining monumental revolutionary vignettes and quotidian practices, Rivera's paintings present Mexican history as a montage of overlapping events, individuals, and symbolic episodes. Eisenstein first met the Mexican muralist in 1927 when Rivera was visiting the Soviet Union to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Russian revolution. Rivera gave Eisenstein a book of reproductions of his monumental murals and according to Eisenstein, "the seed of interest in the country … nourished by the stories of Diego Rivera, when he visited the Soviet Union … grew in a burning desire to travel there …" 20 Despite this burning desire, however, Eisenstein did not go to Mexico until three years later.

In 1928, following the completion of October, Eisenstein left the Soviet Union and travelled and lectured throughout Europe. In 1930 he moved to the United States after Jesse Lasky, on behalf of Paramount Pictures, offered him a short-term contract for $100,000. He arrived in Hollywood in May 1930. Writing in the British journal, Close Up, Clifford Howard asked, "What will Eisenstein do to Hollywood? Or, what will Hollywood do to Eisenstein? That the two should be brought into an attempted confraternity is a circumstance of uncommon moment. An irresistible force meeting an immovable body."21 Although Eisenstein was scornful of much Hollywood cinema, he considered the studios to be in the forefront of technological innovation and thought he could employ these innovations—particularly in color and sound—in his own works. In an article in the New York Times announcing his arrival in the United States, he explained that while he considered the "all talkie" films to be "rotten trash … "

Technique does not stand still. We must be on the job all the time and test every new technical method as to its practibility.… Our new ideology makes us have something to say to the world. And a person with something to say looks for the means to express his thoughts in the most impressive manner. Anything that can be used with the film is welcomed by me, whether it be color or sound. Only a new ideology produces new forms, because it makes you think and forces you to experiment. All the rest is mere 'play.'22

And in an interview in Close Up, he explained, "the future belongs, in my opinion … to the sound film—that is to say, the film in which sound is not used naturalistically … as indicated by the excellent Mickey Mouse films. In these for example, a graceful movement of the foot is accompanied by appropriate music, which is, as it were the audible expression of the mechanical action …" He concluded that, "What the sound film requires is a man with the vision, initiative and courage of Henry Ford." 23 While Henry Ford and Walt Disney seem like strange heroes for the maker of Battleship Potemkin, they are all part of the modernist network I'm discussing. With their emphasis on technological innovation and new forms of technology and communication in the service of various—and often competing—political and aesthetic agendas, Eisenstein, Ford, and Disney all consciously embraced new forms of media to become subjects as well as objects of modernization, to enter and become a part of this modernist network.

Despite his enthusiasm for the possibility to experiment with new filmic technologies, Eisenstein's collaboration with Paramount ultimately failed. Regarding Eisenstein's adaptation of Theodore Drieser's American Tragedy, David O. Selznick wrote to Bud Schulberg, "It was for me a memorable experience; the most moving script I have ever read. It was so effective, it was positively torturing. When I had finished reading it, I was so depressed that I wanted to reach for the bourbon bottle. As entertainment, I don't think it has one chance in a hundred."24 Eisenstein's time in Hollywood was not completely futile, however. While in Los Angeles he worked on a series of theoretical treatises exploring what he saw as the dynamic relationship between the film and the screen. In a speech before the Technicians Branch of the Academy of Motion Pictures of Arts and Sciences, he announced that "the arrival of the wide screen with its opportunities for a new screen shape throws us once more headlong into questions of purely spatial composition. And much more—it affords us the possibility of reviewing and reanalyzing the whole aesthetic of pictorial composition in the cinema …" Extolling

the possibilities of vertical, upright composition … using the opportunity afforded by the advent of wide film to break that loathsome upper party of the frame … which has bent us and obliged us to a passive horizontalism … it is my purpose to defend the cause of the 50 per cent of compositional possibilities exiled from the light of the screen. It is my desire to intone the myth of the male, the strong, the virile, active, vertical composition …

Ultimately, Eisenstein was interested in creating "a "dynamic square screen, that is to say one providing in its dimensions the opportunity of impressing, in projection, with absolute grandeur every geometrically conceivable form of the picture limit.…"25 He was optimistic that given his knowledge of new technological innovations, he could employ this vertical screen approach in his next project, a multi-layered exploration of Mexican history.

Rather than return to the Soviet Union when his Paramount collaboration ended, on the advice of his friend Charlie Chaplin, Eisenstein pitched his Mexican film idea to the socialist author and fellow traveler Upton Sinclair. Sinclair was enthusiastic about the project and between the end of October and Thanksgiving of that year he arranged the necessary permissions for the filmmaker and his crew to travel to Mexico to make a film to be produced by himself, his wife, Mary Craig Kimbrough Sinclair, and three other investors organized as the Mexican Film Trust. On November 24, Eisenstein signed a contract with the Trust which stated that the funding for the project would come from Mary Sinclair in "an amount not less than Twenty-Five Thousand dollars," that the picture be "non-political" but based upon "Eisenstein's desire to be free to direct the making of a picture according to his own ideas of what a Mexican picture should be, and in full faith in Eisenstein's artistic integrity." The agreed-upon shooting schedule was "a period of from three to four months" for a film that would be approximately one hour long, and finally, that "Eisenstein furthermore agrees that all pictures made or directed by him in Mexico, all negative film and positive prints, and all story and ideas embodied in said Mexican picture, will be the property of Mrs. Sinclair.…" A coda to the contract, dated December 1, granted that the "Soviet Government may have the film free for showing inside the U.S.S.R."26

One hundred thousand dollars and fourteen months later, the Sinclairs withdrew funding and Stalin, fearing that Eisenstein was about to defect, recalled the filmmaker to the Soviet Union. Eisenstein never made his Mexican film; the rushes went to Los Angeles then to the Museum of Modern Art in New York (although footage from the film was used in a number of other productions).27 In 1979 Eisenstein's long-time producer and collaborator, Grigory Alexander, put together a film based on Eisenstein's elaborate notes and script for the project.

For a proclaimed communist, Eisenstein's film seems preoccupied with the sumptuousness of material objects—in particular clothing and domestic accessories. The camera repeatedly lingers over young women getting dressed in traditional embroidered tops and skirts, working for gold coins for a dowry, or preparing for a festival; it zooms in on matadors dressing in their majestic ensembles (lush velvet vests, shiny brass buttons, luxurious silk sashes) and on the variety of hats thrown into the ring after the bullt; it catalogues the costumes and decorations of the annual fiestas of the day of the dead and the Virgin of Guadalupe. It registers in detail the earthenware bowls of old women grinding corn, the spurs of a hacienda owner, the jugs of the pulque workers. This is a materialist vision of Mexican history—a history told in images from a number of sources—a montage, a layering of goods and ideas. According to Eisenstein, the film was to be divided into five chapters with a prologue and an epilogue.28 Describing the film to Sinclair, he explained that he conceived of the film as a Mexican serape: "a serape is the striped blanket that every Mexican wears. So striped and violently contrasting are the cultures in Mexico running next to each other and at the same time being centuries away … we took the contrasting adjacency of its violent colors as the motif for constructing our film."29

The serape is a key object in the visual iconography of Mexico. Although the Spanish introduced the technology in the mid 1500, serapes and other hand-woven Mexican textiles have become discernable emblems of Mexican national identity. For example, Diego Rivera repeatedly employed serapes as a motif in his abstract paintings from the early twentieth century to concretely signal Mexico. His Zapatista Landscape painted while he lived a bohemian expatriate life in Montmartre, is a cubist assemblage of Mexican signifiers: a rifle, a sombrero, the grand volcanoes of the Valley of Mexico (Popocatepetl and Iztaccihuatl), and the ubiquitous serape. Similarly he incorporates the serape into his portrait of his friend the journalist Luis Guzman, who travelled with Pancho Villa before being exiled to Spain. By picturing him in a matador's headdress with a serape draped over his shoulder like a cape, Rivera links Guzman directly to Mexico through overt visual cues. 30 Given the relationship between Eisenstein and Rivera, it is not surprising that Eisenstein would choose this textile as the unifying motif behind his kaleidoscopic film. But it also exemplifies the imagined network of modernist icons such as masks, ruins, textiles, sombreros, cacti, skulls, and volcanoes that came to represent Mexico during this period. For many North American and European artists and intellectuals, Mexico was a site for non-industrial inspiration as embodied in these folk objects. For example, the popular American economist Stuart Chase wrote that "it is impossible for Mexicans to produce the humblest thing without form and design. A donkey wears a load of palm leaves arranged on either flank in green sunbursts. Merchants hang candles by their wicks to make patterns in both line and color.… To the traveler from the North, used to the treatment of cold dead produce as cold dead produce, this is a matter of perpetual wonder and delight."31 Similarly, Katherine Anne Porter gushed that "It would be difficult to explain in a very few words how the Mexicans have enriched their national life through the medium of their native arts. It is in everything they do and are … the passion for individual expression without hypocrisy, which is the true genius of the race."32

Mexico was also, however, a site for experimentation, a place to test new forms of media and technology. Like Spratling in his jewelry workshop, the photographers Edward Weston, Paul Strand, and Tina Modotti, played with both modernist conventions and new technologies in the images they produced while in Mexico. Like Eisenstein and Los Tres Grandes, their works often focused on distinctly Mexican things in abstract compositions. Paul Strand's Woman – Patzcuaro (1930s) from his Mexican Portfolio, for example, features a native woman wrapped in a large woven scarf holding a straw basket [re 3] and in Portrait of Two Men, Mexico, also from the Mexican Portfolio, the epynonymous men peer out from a doorway. Dressed all in white, they both wear traditional leather belts and one wears a distinctive sombrero to mark them as Mexican. The scarf, the basket, the belts, and the sombrero are all part of the vernacular network of Mexican objects yet Strand employs them in a distinctly modernist idiom. Similarly, Tina Modotti's revolutionary still lifes Images for a Mexican Song and Bandolier with Hammer and Sickle both reference a modernist vocabulary of distinctly Mexican objects. In Images for a Mexican Song a dried ear of corn, a string of bullets, and the base of a guitar intersect in a bifurcated triad. Through their cropped juxtapositioning the strings of the guitar, the bullets in the belt, and the kernels in the corn create a series of almost abstract repeating patterns; yet they never lose the specificity of their Mexican referents. Similarly in Bandolier with Hammer and Sickle, the c-curve of a well-used sickle artfully embraces a bullet-filled bandolier and an ear of corn. In both images the objects flirt with becoming abstract shapes floating in space while they maintain their specific historical context within Mexican revolutionary history. While the subject matter of these images is distinctly Mexican, both Strand and Modotti intentionally experimented with cropping their picture planes to defy conventional spatial relations; in so doing they created modernist vernacular still lifes and portraits that bridge the local and the universal in both form and content. The Mexican works of Edward Weston further exploit this tension between the universal and the local by reducing key Mexican visual tropes—pre-Columbian ruins, Maguey cacti, earthenware pottery—to abstract compositions. Eisenstein employed a similar visual vocabulary in Que Viva Mexico. The film is filled with epic landscapes, local vignettes, and the syncretism of pre-Columbian and Catholic ritual and pageantry. It is like a mural in animated form.
