Indeed, much of Que Viva Mexico is influenced by the work of the Mexican muralists. Like Rivera, Orozco, and Siqueiros, whose work he assiduously studied, Eisenstein was a key part of the modernist Mexican network. Through his film he intentionally aimed to create a dynamic, horizontal narrative to be projected on the walls.33 This resonated closely with his idea of the dynamic screen that he was developing while in Hollywood. Indeed, while in Taxco, Eisenstein was revising his lecture to the Academy of Motion Picture Technicians into an essay entitled "The Dynamic Square" for the British journal Close Up in which he spoke of "approximating the cinema to the stage," and called for the creation of a "monster screen—four times the usual size." Eisenstein began directly experimenting with these techniques in Que Viva Mexico and credited the muralists directly with the conceptualization of his new dynamic style. According to Olivier Debroise, "While unable to cut the film's frames as in a photomontage, Eisenstein made an important contribution by inventing vertical editing within a single plane, based on Rivera and Siqueiros' propositions." The murals also had an effect on how he conceived of the narrative and the style of the film. According to Eisenstein, one of the things he liked about murals was that they forced the spectator to physically move through space (and time). With cinema, the film moved and the viewer sat still, with the monumental public murals, the viewer moved.34

Like the muralists and other modernists at work in Mexico at the time, Eisenstein self-consciously incorporated pre-Columbian motifs, Mexican folk music, and multiple, overlapping story lines into his work. He made direct reference to the influence of muralists throughout the film and planned to dedicate the third chapter of the film, which dealt with the Maguey cactus and the pulque workers to Rivera. 35 Although he never met Orozco, Eisenstein considered him the Dionysus to Rivera's Apollo and planned to dedicate the final chapter of film to him. But while in Mexico he was perhaps most influenced by Siqueiros, with whom he discussed his dynamic square theory while staying in Taxco and to whom he dedicated the prologue of the film which featured the burial of a young man according to pre-Columbian rituals—a sequence he credited to Siqueiros' Burial of the Martyred Worker for the National Preparatory School which depicted the body of a worker in a casket covered with a hammer and sickle.

Like a network, this energy and inspiration simultaneously flowed both ways. Siqueiros was also influenced by Eisenstein on both a personal and artistic level. In his murals from the 1930s he repeatedly experimented with adapting Eisenstein's frame editing theories to large-scale mural painting and he dedicated his essay on the "Vehicles of Dialectic, Subversive Painting" with "admiration to Sergei Mikhailovitch Eisenstein." Although he was confined to easel painting while exiled in Taxco, Siqueiros was still profoundly interested in the composition and form that murals could take. 36 When he was forced to leave Mexico a year later for further "subversive" activities, he traveled to Los Angeles where he resumed his mural practice and painted three works: Mitin Obrero ("Workers' Meeting") at the Chouinard School of Art, América Tropical at the Plaza Art Center, and Retrato Actual de México ("Current Portrait of Mexico") in a private residence at Santa Monica, now in the Santa Barbara Museum of Art.

Like Eisenstein, Siqueiros was warmly received in the United States.37 In Los Angeles he socialized with Hollywood luminaries such as Katharine Hepburn, Charles Laughton, and Marlene Dietrich and was invited to speak at a variety of political and cultural events. He did not, however, tone down his politics. In a 1932 lecture entitled "Rectification About the Plastic Arts in Mexico," he argued that artists could not remain indifferent "to the struggle which will liberate humanity and art," but should "collaborate aesthetically and individually with the class historically predestined to change anew our present society."38 And in a talk before the Los Angeles John Reed Club (the cultural arm of the Communist Party USA) on the topic of "The Vehicles of Dialectic –Subversive Painting," he announced the arrival of

a revolutionary aesthetic … the plastic form of the final proletarian struggle against the capitalistic state; a form that will have nothing in common with the dry forms of the past, nor with the eccentric 'snob' forms of the present. This form will be neither academic nor modernist; it shall be dialectic and subversive, that is to say, logically materialistic, objective, dynamic. 39

Like Eisenstein, Siqueiros was interested taking advantage of the technological possibilities afforded him in the United States, in this case these were industrial materials such as poured cement and building machinery like air guns and compressors. Siqueiros profoundly believed that cement murals had the potential to be a distinctly new media. Unlike the "dry" fresco forms of the past, he aimed to create a performative and dynamic new type of mural painting that would be collective as well as individual, local as well as global in its reach.

Siqueiros described his new technique and its ideological implications in detail in his treatise on "The Vehicles of Dialectic, Subversive Painting" which began with the announcement that "the traditional fresco … is socially dead—the modern fresco, technically adapted to modern conditions, is the only one that has possibilities for development." In manifesto-like language he called for the radical transformation of modern painting using new tools and materials:

The instruments of music have been revolutionized periodically throughout the history of the world. The elements and instruments of architectural production have likewise undergone radical transformation throughout the ages. On the other hand, the elements and instruments of pictorial production have not been modified in the least. The modern painter who is not commercial or an industrial producer is still using elements and instruments of hundred years ago … The Block of Mural Painters is using to great advantage the modern elements and instruments that science and mechanics give to the men of today.… To the anachronistic elements corresponds an anachronistic aesthetic. An integrally modern and revolutionary plastic aesthetic can only be produced with corresponding instruments.

Siqueiros intended to demonstrate these dialectical-subversive practices in his first LA mural, Workers' Meeting, for the Chouinard School of Art, where he had been hired to teach fresco painting.40 His workshop-style classes allowed him to experiment with both his aesthetic ideology and technique, which he saw as organically linked. He explained, "It was the practice of painting, the logic of uninterrupted exercise that made theory possible for me. Theory is discovered in that which is being done and in a certain way the theory anticipates that which the later comes organically."41 According to his partner at the time, Blanca Luz, who regularly sent dispatches on the progress of the mural back to the Mexico City newspaper El Universal, "In two weeks, with three spray guns and twenty North American painters David Alfaro Siqueiros finished the fresco art at the Chouinard School of Art." Through her articles for the paper, Luz chronicled the evolution of Siqueiros' style and the radical new potential it embodied for the industrial age for an international audience. One of the key points Luz highlighted was Siqueiros' desire to move beyond the idea of a "Mexican" national style in his art and become part of a distinctly modernist network. Although, like Eisenstein, Siqueiros was repulsed by the blatant capitalism of the United States, he was also impressed by its machinations and was dependent on material objects, such as airguns and compressors to communicate with his audience across national boundaries. According to Luz, Siqueiros felt "the Mexican fresco" was "unsuitable" in the United States because:

it is slow, because it is mystical and because in a vertiginous and violent city of capitalism it is archaic. Where skyscrapers are raised in twenty-four hours it is not possible to install the romantic fresco that takes three, four, and ten years to paint.… The new elements … had opened up a new world, an unsuspected aesthetic: trim, solid, electric, definite, concrete. It was the aesthetic of this epoch, it is the aesthetic of the developing new society.42

While Workers' Meeting employed the tools of the United States' capitalist infrastructure in its creation, it strongly critiqued the country in its content. According to Siqueiros, its "object was to combat the anti-democratic politics of racial discrimination in the south of the United States."43 Today images of Workers' Meeting are difficult to find since the mural was destroyed shortly after it was created, but Grace Clemente, speaking to the LA John Reed Club, described it thus:

two rows of workers, from the roof and scaffold of a building look down with intentness upon a gesticulating street speaker. The Negro on his right and the women on his left, each carrying a child, as well as the workers above, indicate by their earnest attention that the speaker's message is of great importance. The speaker is recognizable as a communist by his red shirt. Though we are agreed that in reality communists do not wear such marks of identification which would inevitably sponsor police brutality, they must be considered permissible in plastic when symbols must be used.

The choice of the red shirt to designate the worker as a communist serves as a form of visual shorthand much like those employed by Eisenstein, Rivera, Weston and other artists at the time. Although Clement acknowledges that in reality the worker most likely would have avoided red to prevent notice and perhaps evade police brutality, Siqueiros intentionally played into popular media representations that linked the color red to communist agitation. He deliberately chose to cite a recognizable network of objects, easily identified symbols, and militant tropes such as the red shirt, the black worker, and the mother and child, to visually communicate his politics and forecast his hopes for a racially integrated, idealized future.

In Workers' Meeting Siqueiros began to experiment directly with the techniques he had discussed with Eisenstein in Mexico and developed in his treatise on dialectical subversive painting. Like Eisenstein, he was interested in the dynamic potential of two-dimensional spaces. He literally wanted his works to extend beyond the picture plane into everyday life. Central to this was his embrace of new technologies. He explained, "After making the first sketch we used the camera and the motion picture to aid us in elaboration of our first drawing.… In the preparation of our walls we adopted the pneumatic drill to roughen the wall surface and give greater adhesion to the finished coating of plaster, which was applied with an air gun. The airbrush we considered an essential instrument in the plastic production of our decoration." 44 Today Siqueiros's enthusiasm for the airbrush and the pneumatic drill as revolutionary tools may seem funny to us, but he sincerely believed that modern industrial equipment would quickly and efficiently make true fresco painting possible and that true fresco painting could be a revolutionary form. Like Eisenstein and Spratling, he embraced new technologies and vernacular traditions in his art practices to bridge the local and the universal to create a complex form of global modernism.

By focusing on the intersection of local and universal forms of modernism as they intersect in the lives of Spratling, Siqueiros, and Eisenstein we can clearly see the existence of a modernist network—one that crosses national borders, artistic mediums, and political ideologies. All three men embraced new technologies to create a visual language of real and imagined Mexican tropes. Spratling and his native workers used contemporary machinery to produce "authentic" pre-Columbian pieces for a primarily expatriate market; Eisenstein employed Hollywood techniques and equipment in his filmic quest for dynamism, and Siqueiros championed the use of the spray gun, the pneumonic drill and poured concrete as new revolutionary media that would help usher in a true proletariat public art form. All three men also used material goods to signify meaning in their works; through serapes, silver bracelets, red shirts, and woven baskets they employed a vocabulary of things to signify "Mexico" to an international audience. From Moscow to Hollywood, from New Orleans to Mexico City, they constituted a modernist network of images, ideas, and artifacts that both questioned and made sense of the modern world. By looking at how they juxtaposed the vernacular with the cosmopolitan, the sombrero with the beret, we can gain a better sense of the real and imagined networks that sustained the political, aesthetic, ideological and market forces that not only brought these three men to Taxco in 1931 but which frame our understandings of the history of global modernism.

A. Joan Saab  

A. Joan Saab is Associate Professor of Art History and Director of the Graduate Program in Visual and Cultural Studies at the University of Rochester. The author of For the Millions: American Art and Culture between the Wars, she is currently working on a book entitled Modernist Networks: Modern Art and the American Marketplace.

1. A Key metaphor of modernity for Michel Foucault is that of the network. He writes, "We are in the epoch of simultaneity: we are in the epoch of juxtaposition, the epoch of the near and far, of the side-by-side, of the dispersed. We are at a moment, I believe, when our experience of the world is less that of a long life developing through time than that of a network that connects points and intersects with its own skein. "Michel Foucault, "What is Enlightenment," ("Qu'est-ce que les Lumières ?"), in Rabinow (P.), éd., The Foucault Reader, New York, Pantheon Books, 1984, pp. 32–50. Network is a useful metaphor for me as well. In its simplest definition, a network is a "complex, interconnected group or system," or "a chain of interconnected people or operations." In information technology, "a network is a series of points or nodes interconnected by communication paths." Networks can interconnect with other networks and contain sub-networks. www.thefreedictionary.dom/network; Oxford American Dictionary (NY: Avon Books, 1980) 598.

2. Miriam Hansen, "The Mass Production of the Senses: Classical Cinema as Vernacular Modernism," 6.2 60.

3. Modernism remains a slippery concept to define. On the one hand, Marshall Berman's 1988 conception of the term as "any attempt by modern men and women to become subjects as well as objects of modernization, to get a grip on the modern world and make themselves at home in it," remains the best definition. Marshal Berman, All that is Solid Melts into Air (New York: Simon and Schuster, 1982) 5–6. But as Juan Suarez recently has argued, "postmodernism authorized the recasting of modernism as a cultural moment that foreshadowed contemporary interests—and therefore purveyed a more usable past." In the past thirty years, the voices and practices of women, queers, and people of color have challenged the dominant formalist narratives of modernism which located production in a handful of metropolitan centers and applauded detached abstractions and flat picture frames. Pop Modernism: Noise and the Reinvention of the Everyday (Champaign: University of Illinois Press, 2007), 2. Following Michel Foucault, I see modernity as "an attitude [rather] than as a period of history." By attitude Foucault specifies that he "mean[s] a mode of relating to contemporary reality; a voluntary choice made by certain people; in the end a way of thinking and feeling; a way, too, of acting and behaving that at one and the same time marks a relation of belonging and presents itself as a task. Michel Foucault, "What is Enlightenment," ("Qu'est-ce que les Lumières ?"), in Rabinow (P.), éd., The Foucault Reader, New York, Pantheon Books, 1984, pp. 32–50.

5. For more on Modernism in Mexico see Nestor Garcia Canclini, Transforming Modernity (Austin: University of Texas Press, 1992) and Hybrid Cultures: Strategies for Entering and Leaving Modernity (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1995); George Yudice, The Expediency of Culture: Uses of Culture in the Global Era (Durham: Duke University Press, 2003) and Octavio Paz, The Labyrinth of Solitude (New York: Grove Press, 1994).

28. According to Eisenstein's notes, published in Karetnikova Mexico According to Eisenstein, the film was to be organized as such:

Prologue: Dedicated to Siqueiros' Burial of a Mexican Worker, this episode chronicles the funeral rituals of young man. Set amid pre-Colubinan ruins according to Eisenstein's notes, "Time is Eternity. It might be today. It might be twenty years ago … might be a thousand."

Chapter One: Conquest focuses on three Christ-like penitents as they make the stations of the cross. Focusing on the brutality of the Spanish Catholic conquest, it also highlights the syncretisim of Catholicism with indigenous rituals.

Chapter Two: Sandunga. Set in the province of Tehuantepec, this chapter chronicles the coming of age of a young girl named Concepcion, her courtship and marriage to young man named Abundio and her motherhood. Focusing on the relationships between matriarchal society and a love of nature, this is the most lighthearted and optimistic of the sequences.

Chapter Three: Fiesta follows a young matador as he prepares and then participates in a bullt.

Chapter Four: Maguey is set at a pulque-producing hacienda in the province of Hidalgo between fields of the Maguey cactus. Dedicated to Diego Rivera, this segment contains the brutal rape of a young woman and the torture and murder of her fiancé and his brothers.

Chapter Five. Soldadera. This episode was never shot but was inspired by the work José Clemente Orozco which focused on the participation of women in the Mexican Revolution.

Epilogue. The camera captures ecstatic imagery of the celebrations of the Day of the Death and the Calavera. Inspired by the popular prints of the folk artist Jose Guadalupe Posada, the ending is ambivalent.

Project MUSE Journals Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011 Al Qaeda and the Avant-Garde: Towards a Genealogy of the Taliah

Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

Al Qaeda and the Avant-Garde:
Towards a Genealogy of the Taliah
Mike Sell

The emergence of the taliah

A month after nineteen men crashed four jet airliners into Manhattan's World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and a clod-strewn field in Western Pennsylvania, and only hours after the U.S. military invaded Afghanistan, Al Jazeera television, the most-watched network in the Arab world, broadcast a video recording it had received through secret channels. On it, Osama bin Laden, charismatic leader of the international terrorist network Al Qaeda, condemned the invasion and praised the hijackers, glorifying them as "a blessed group of vanguard Muslims, the forefront of Islam."1

As someone who had studied the art, history, and theory of the avant-garde for some time, my curiosity was piqued, but I was also deeply skeptical. U.S. news organizations were scrambling to find reliable translators, and cultural misunderstandings were obviously prevalent across U.S. culture. It was hard not to come to the conclusion that the transcript was a murky cocktail of sloppy translation and the uncritical, ahistorical sense of "vanguard" so common in scholarly literature, the popular press, and online marketing. Or, even if I were to presume that the translation was on target, what bin Laden was invoking was that "other" avant-garde, the military/political one of Bolsheviks and hinterland guerrillas, the kind of vanguard that we generally assume has little pertinence to the kinds of questions those in avant-garde studies generally ask. A curiosity, nothing more—a tidbit for the clippings file.

Or so I thought. I have learned since that "vanguard" is a perfectly suitable translation of the Arabic word taliah (sometimes transliterated taliyaah or talihah).2 The term is used in the Arab world today with the same promiscuity as it is elsewhere and scholars study it with the same fervor. Further, as one perceptive reader of this essay noted, there is a common strain of prophetic theology and violent activism that binds East and West for centuries. Add to that the research I've been doing on the role of Saint-Simonian ideology in the colonization of Algeria and the persistent Orientalism that shaped the avant-garde into a cultural (as opposed to merely technocratic) tendency, and it's hard not to come to the conclusion that bin Laden's encomium is only the most recent artifact from a history of material, social, ideological, and cultural exchange that has intertwined vanguards across the U.S., Western Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa.3

Fair enough, but what benefits are there to bringing Islamist vanguards such as Al Qaeda into the scholarly fold? First, the taliah suggests that the line drawn by most scholars between the "two avant-gardes," as Renato Poggioli puts it,4 between the artistic and the military/political, is hampering our ability to comprehend the history of the avant-garde more generally. While some scholars enthusiastically embrace a concept of the avant-garde that brings together the military, culinary, religious, and other traditions of cultural resistance and revolt, that number is still surprisingly low. However, as Richard Schechner writes in a recent PMLA article, "Aestheticizing and ritualizing violence, not as representations (as in the visual arts, theater, or other media), but as actual acts performed in the here and now, are widespread."5 He further notes that "the West and the jihadists occupy very separate spheres from the point of view of values while sharing the same global system from the point of view of techniques."6 Indeed, the taliah reminds us that the distinctions among these varied spheres are always culturally and historically specific.

The taliah presses us to develop a more encompassing definition of the avant-garde, one that subsumes art and aesthetic dissidence under a broader rubric of culture. While many scholars of the avant-garde have moved into a full-on cultural studies mode (Raymond Williams, Barrett Watten, and Richard Schechner coming most quickly to mind7), the field as a whole still privileges aesthetic analysis over historical and ideological analysis, if only by dint of its unwavering, unquestioning commitment to the arts. A broader concept of cultural activism does not mean the end of arts-based analysis, but it does enable us not only to consider a wider range of actions and positions, but, in doing so, adds needed nuance to our understanding of aesthetic politics. Pace Schechner, we should not let values block critical analysis.

Finally, the tale of the taliah affirms James Harding's assertion that the avant-garde is not an essentially "European" tendency, but a "fundamentally global cultural phenomenon" that has emerged in diverse forms and places . The taliah is an exemplary "rough edge," to recall Harding's metaphor, evidence that the avant-garde is a mutable, site-specific product of negotiation, struggle, and mutual transformation rather than a monolithic, linear tendency within European modernity. It is across such rough edges that the most astonishing effects of bringing the taliah into the story of the avant-garde come into view. Andrea Flores Khalil, one of the few critics who has studied the taliah (at least one part of it), suggests exactly how confusing things can get. The taliah, she writes, possesses "a strange, circular, temporal effect …, always returning and moving ahead at the same time."8 Richard Schechner considers this one of the more interesting tendencies in avant-garde art over the last few decades, asserting that

there is no area, be it Micronesia, the Pacific Rim, West Africa, the Circumpolar Region, or wherever, which does not have artists actively trying to use, appropriate, reconcile, come to terms with, exploit, understand—the words and political tone vary, but the substance doesn't—the relationships between local cultures in their extreme, particular historical development and the increasingly complex and multiple contacts and interactions not only among various cultures locally and regionally, but on a global and interspecific scale.9

While not all artists and movements who do this are avant-garde, it is certainly true of the avant-garde that Khalil writes about and the one I'll explore in the following pages. Very much in the vein of Schechner's "tradition-seeking avant-garde," the taliah paradoxically follows and precedes European modernity, and doing so within a sociocultural "rough edge," it is both an influence on and a creature of European modernity. The taliah, a rough-edge, tradition-seeking avant-garde, is further evidence that it is time for scholars to abandon conventional, linear history and embrace instead a genealogical approach à la Foucault, one in which the avant-garde is not a substantive, unitary agent that follows a linear, developmental story, but is, instead, deployed as a critical concept, a marker that identifies and links situated domains of knowledge whose relationship to each other is motile and mercurial.10

Fortunately, Khalil is not entirely alone in recognizing the importance of the taliah. The relationship between Surrealism and the Arab world, especially the French Surrealist group's public support for the Rif rebellion in Morocco, has been the subject of fairly extensive scholarship.11 The impact of the Arab world on the Black Arts Movement has been mapped by Melani McAlister. Of particular importance, she shows how the Nation of Islam, changed feelings about Israel sparked by the 1967 Arab-Israeli War, and Pan-Arab nationalism were touchstones for Black Arts Movement vanguardists Amiri Baraka, Ishmael Reed, Sonia Sanchez, Larry Neal, and others.12 Paul Berman's 2003 article in The New York Times Magazine on Egyptian theologian Sayyid Qutb first alerted me to the widespread presence of vanguard models within radical Islam.13 Historians Gilles Kepel and Adnan Musallam provide a textured sense of the avant-garde as both rhetorical trope and socio-political strategy for Islamic vanguards.14 In an essay on avant-garde drama in the Middle East, Marvin Carlson inveighs against "two widespread and erroneous assumptions"; one, that the Middle East lacks a strong tradition of drama and, two, that European drama is the predominant influence on modern Middle Eastern playwrights and theater artists. Carlson cites Peter J. Chelkowski's work on Iranian performance, which shows that avant-garde drama in the Middle East is most prominent in popular forms such as religious celebrations, dramatic narratives, and festival processions. For Chelkowski, what is avant-garde about these things is, in Carlson's words, "its mixing of materials from history, legend, popular culture, and everyday life; its casual use of found material and space; its frank acknowledge of the apparatus of production; and its breaking down of the barrier between performance and audience."15

But Khalil's The Arab Avant-Garde: Experiments in North African Art and Literature stands apart in its understanding of the historiographical implications of the taliah. Investigating experimental literature in North Africa, mostly written in French, Khalil positions it within "the recent and still partial emergence of minority literatures and marginalized voices into an international, global discourse," especially as it relates to the "tensions between local and global, traditional and modern, authentic and general …"16 In line with Schechner, she shows poets such as Abdelwahab Meddeb evincing a "desire to draw new relations between their past and their future." Meddeb's writings demonstrate the ways a "minor literature" can upset local conrations of cultural authority without abiding strictly within the contours of European modernism.

This is why chronology gets so tangled; to understand the taliah (not a term Khalil uses), we must approach it "through a multiple genealogy and not just … a singular origin."17 Meddeb understood "cultural modernity" as a "cyclical recommencing: French being inhabited by its colonial relationship with the Maghreb, and Arabic likewise speaking through the vocabularies of European thinkers."18 The implications of this are profound. "This decentering on a worldwide scale," Khalil concludes, "produces a critical transformation, one disturbing the Western canon, the other dismantling the value systems of traditional cultures from which writers and artists originated and have dispersed."19 Both sides are changed; they are mutual influences.

Al Qaeda, Sayyid Qutb, and the "first" avant-garde

To recall, when I read Osama bin Laden praising the 9/11 hijackers as "a blessed group of vanguard Muslims, the forefront of Islam," I was both dubious and curious. Post-9/11 paranoia, the revelation of sleeper cells in London and Madrid, the insurgencies in Afghanistan and Iraq, the maneuverings of Hamas in Israel/Palestine, the camps of Peshawar—these pushed me to find out more. But there was another reason for doing research on Al Qaeda and Islamic militancy more generally. I'd been thinking about whether avant-garde theory could be applied to non-art subjects such as the U.S. Christian evangelical movement or counterinsurgency operations. That effort was proving fruitful, but there was a limit to it in that none of the groups and movements I was studying explicitly claimed the title "avant-garde." They were, as Matei Calinescu would put it, "unconscious avant-gardes."20

This is definitely not the case with radical Islamism. Many Islamist organizations and intellectuals take the vanguard title consciously, and many of those have a fully developed theory of cultural power and social organization, two pillars of any avant-garde theory. The Egyptian Hassan al Banna, for one, modeled the Muslim Brotherhood after the Russian Bolsheviks and the fascist Phalangists of Spain. That said, Brotherhood chapters are typically reformist, grassroots organizations rather than vanguard parties. It is true that in Egypt a hardcore underground organization was formed in the 1960s when the party found itself under intense repression by the Nasser regime, and accusations of terrorist support and sympathy continue to follow chapters across the Islamic world. Regardless, one would be on slippery ground to call the Brotherhood an "avant-garde."21

A fuller and more mature conception of the Islamic avant-garde is evident in the writings of Maulana Sayyid Abdul Ala Maududi of Pakistan, founder of Jamaat-e-Islami. For him, vanguardism was both an organizational and ethical model for breaking with a corrupt society. It also perfectly fit the contours of Islamic history. Maududi's vision of the taliah was modeled on the hijra, the exile and insurgency of Mohammad and his followers. Gilles Kepel notes that, in a number of texts written in the 1930s and 40s, "Maududi made explicit references to the 'vanguard' of the earliest Muslims, who gathered around the Prophet in 622 during the hijra, broke with the idolatrous people of Mecca, and departed to found the Islamic state of Medina. His own party was intended to follow a similar course."22 Maududi was not the first to do this; Jamal al-Din al-Afghani (1838–97) and Mohammad 'Abduh (1849–1905) also did so. However, those two viewed it as an example rather than an organizational or strategic model, as Maududi did. However, as close as Maududi came to considering the hijra an indigenous model of vanguard activism, he ultimately proved unfaithful to the concept. Though he called for a break with jahiliyya society (a term I'll discuss in more detail shortly), he never broke with the political establishment in Pakistan and never advocated violence. Keppel writes, "Maududi's holy war to build an Islamic state found expression through full participation in the political system of Pakistan, rather than radical opposition to it."23

A more literal reading of the hijra as "instruction to be translated into action," is found in the work of Egyptian theologian Sayyid Qutb, rightly considered the most important influence on radical Islamism today. (His brother Mohammad was one of Osama bin Laden's teachers.) In his highly influential 1964 book Milestones, Qutb urges "the callers to Islam in every country and in every period [to] give thought to one particular aspect of the history of Islam and … ponder over it deeply"; specifically, "the generation of the Companions of the Prophet, may God be pleased with them."24 The hijra, Qutb asserts, is more than metaphor and example; it is a model for action, a concept of historical agency, and an ethos. In sum, Qutb viewed the hijra as the most effective means to manifest the differences between the community of true believers and the disbelieving majority culture, known as jahiliyya.

As John Voll notes, "Before Qutb, the word jahiliyya simply refered to the period before the time of the Prophet Mohammad or to those people at the time of Mohammad who did not know about him. However, Qutb used the term inclusively, extending it to all who rebelled willfully against God's rule."25 Reflecting his abiding (though ambivalent) contempt for European modernity, Qutb calls both for a break between "present and his past" and with the "jahiliyya environment, its customs and traditions, its ideas and concepts." The vanguard, Qutb writes, "which sets out … and then keeps walking on the path … should keep itself somewhat aloof from this all-encompassing jahiliyya…"26 The vanguard, in Qutb's view, enacts a rupture both within time and community. Though he doesn't deny that some ties with this fallen society should be maintained out of necessity, Qutb proclaims that "we will not change our own values and concepts either more or less to make a bargain with this jahiliyya society. Never! We and it are on different roads, and if we take even one step in its company, we will lose our goal entirely and lose our way as well."27

Two readings, two histories

What can we make of such language, which is so clearly indebted to Western worldviews, both long-lived and recent? As I've considered this, I've developed two very different readings of this "rough edge." The first would characterize Qutb's hijra rhetoric as a cynical ploy, a hypocritical hanging of Islamic window dressing on an essentially European concept. There's good evidence to support this reading. In addition to not having to admit the European pedigree of his strategy, Qutb can neatly sweep under the rug the influence on his thinking of the liberal-constitutional Wafd Party, which Qutb damned as jahiliya only upon his break with it in the late 1940s.28 This wouldn't be the first time Qutb altered history to fit ideology. In 1952, he proposed that Egyptian history textbooks be revised in order to "to correct the distortions … which failed to give an appropriate place to the Islamic renaissance as represented by the Wahhabiyah and the Mahdiyah movements" of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, which predated the major wave of European colonization and the dissemination of Western thought.29

In support of such a reading, Voll writes, "It is clear that the Islamic resurgence is not primarily the accomplishment of those with little experience with, or knowledge of, the modern West. Indeed, those who constitute the hard core of the current Islamist wave have had intensive and unprecedented exposure to the technologies, educational systems and philosophies, political processes, cultural values, and lifestyles of the West."30 That was definitely true of Qutb, who was educated in a modern primary school rather than a traditional Qura'nic school (i.e., a kuttab) and felt perfectly at ease making fun of those educated in such places. He was an accomplished scholar of European romantic poetry and a good poet himself, favoring the romantic mode. Qutb was drawn to other aspects of European modernity, too. According to Voll, Qutb admired the "major rationalist modernists of the 1920s and 1930s."31

He wasn't alone in this regard. Western modernists have enjoyed high regard in the Arab world since at least the reign of Mohammad 'Ali (1769–1849), who, inspired by Napoleon, "began a program of rapid modernization of the Egyptian military, government, and economy using Western European advisers and models."32 And though the modernists could not avoid being challenged by those who "called for a return to the example of the pious ancestors, the companions of the Prophet … Islamic modernism provided fundamentalism with a sophisticated modern vocabulary for the defense of Islam"; specifically, a "focus on secularism and materialism as problems at the core of the modern experience."33 In sum, rather than viewing Qutb as anti-European and anti-American, as most have, we should follow Musallam's lead and consider him the result of "conflicting forces of tradition and modernity in Egyptian society which were working to shape his personality and world view."34 The hijra rhetoric is something of a red herring—radical Islamism replicates the worst features of Eurocentrism: violence, intolerance, elitism.

But this is not the only way to interpret the data. A second interpretation of Qutb's use of the hjijra myth puts the sleight of hand to the Europeans, artist and scholar alike. There is an extensive body of scholarship that shows Islam to be a deep and significant influence on romanticism.35 Naji B. Ouejian writes,

To the romantics, the East was a model world of exoticism, and what helped popularize such an image of the East was a very old Western tradition which started way before politics and trade had forced the Orient on the attention of the Western peoples; it started with the Westerners' amazement that the East, and not the West, should have been the birthplace of almost all ancient civilizations and of heavenly religions, particularly Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.36

And, of course, romanticism was a deep and significant influence on the avant-garde. As Renato Poggioli pointed out in The Theory of the Avant-Garde (Italian, 1962), the avant-garde is inconceivable without romanticism, and "[m]any historians and critics have affirmed the continuity … between romanticism and avant-gardism." However, he continues, "almost always, this involves rightists, often polemicists, already hostile to romanticism, who attack the avant-garde as an extreme case of what they call the 'disease of romanticism.'"37 Perhaps this hostility to romanticism is the reason why scholars have mostly ignored the influence of Islam on the avant-garde (or is it the reverse, hostility to Islam amplifying a predisposition against romanticism?). Qutb's affinity with the tendency would only provide one more reason to ignore him.

The metaphor may be part of the problem, too. The military connotations of "avant-garde" obscure other paradigms that are just as useful for imagining small-group cultural radicalism: the cenacle, the rhizome, the think tank, or, of particular interest here, the mystical pilgrimage. The mystical pilgrimage was a common chronotope for romantic poets, as Oueijan points out:

It is difficult to read extensively in the works of the romantics without coming away with the feeling that there emanates from their writings a sense of determination to explore the mysteries of existing yet obscure realities. Their insistence on a voyage or a pilgrimage away from conventional civilization manifested itself in two forms: a physical (Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage) and/or a mental (Coleridge's The Ancient Mariner) quest toward the exotic and mysterious.38

Examples of romantic literature in which Islam res prominently are numerous. Shelley, Byron, William Beckford, and Goethe—just to cite the big names—all tried their hands at it. Though it would be incorrect to remove such poets and their work from the broader, demeaning Orientalist treatment of the Arab world that prevailed, some romantics approached Islam with seriousness and respect.

Dan White has drawn my attention to a particularly interesting example of a poem that demonstrates such respect, Robert Southey and Coleridge's "Mohammed."39 Begun in 1799 by Southey, the poem languished for a few years before being picked up again when Coleridge offered to help out, but the collaboration didn't get too far. In the fragment, Mohammad's brother Ali disguises himself as the Prophet in order to deceive their enemies, enabling Mohammad to escape and hide in a warren of caves. That disguise is cloaked in yet another: Ali is "restless and full of fear, yet semblant of one that is sleeping." Upon discovery, the disguise causes further confusion. The substitution of one brother for another befuddles the enemies of Islam and goads them into a panicky, disordered chase across Arabia and North Africa. The scene then shifts to a cave in which Mohammad and one of his Companions hide, passing "expectant hours," their hope giving to "the sound of the wind … its tone" and to the Prophet the promise that "God will confound" the plots of his enemies. The fragment contains a cluster of tried-and-true vanguard themes: self-imposed exile, moralistic interpretation of space and history, sensory and intellectual sensitivity granted by dissidence, the world-historical significance of contrarian attitudes and action, and performance. Incidentally, it also invokes the kinds of ambiguity, performativity, and exotic self-fashioning that are typical of "rough edge" vanguard groupings and that continually baffle scholars commited to linear, Eurocentric models of avant-garde history.

Returning to Qutb, then, I think we find that the issue of influence is more complicated than either interpretation allows on its own. Indeed, there's no way to finally and firmly decide which of the two interpretations of Qutb's hijra rhetoric is more valid. Both Qutb and the historians of the avant-garde have some answering to do. Again, as Musallam puts it, Qutb fashioned himself within "conflicting forces of tradition and modernity in Egyptian society which were working to shape his personality and world view."40 Thus, I personally find it most suitable to read Qutb's theology as the protean creature of a turbulent rough edge between Europe and the Arab world, a boundary comprised of multiple negotiations, discourses, and performances. Rather than arguing whether Qutb's taliah is authentic or hypocritical, it is more productive and far more interesting to consider it as "both/and."

Conclusion

Though Al Qaeda is only a small part of its history, I think it suggests the benefits of bringing the taliah into the historiographical fold. The kinds of questions scholars who study the avant-garde have begun asking about race, gender, the state and its institutions, colonialism, and other matters come into sharper focus as a consequence—and also different focus. For too long, we've assumed that these issues are distinctively European; they are that, no doubt, but they are also informed by other places, other histories. Avant-garde theory, in turn, provides a remarkably solvent discursive framework for us to comparatively study numerous sites and moments where the taliah appears, places like bohemian ballets and novels, the heated debates of Henri de Saint-Simon and his disciples, the polished corridors of the École de Médecine (where doctors debated the best way to aid the colonial project in Algeria), the dusty roads travelled by Frantz Fanon, Gamal Nasser's dungeons, the Islamic sleeper cells of 9/11, and the restive youth of Paris's suburban ghettos. Understood as a complex historical and geopolitical contact zone, the taliah—a term I now view as synonymous with "avant-garde" or "vanguard"—allows us to think about the avant-garde in a more nuanced, global, and richly textured way. Understood as an exemplary rough edge, as a place where linear history must give way to the situational analyses of Foucault-style genealogy, the taliah inspires us to understand better the kinds of interventions into hierarchies and power flows that have been and might be carried out by avant-gardes. Most importantly, it restores the issue of terror to rightful prominence within avant-garde studies. The taliah is implicated in the deepest violence: the violence of colonization and its countermovements; the violence of ethnocentrism, both the direct violence of punch and insult and the indirect violence of hopelessness; and the violence of culture shock; and the fires of terrorism. More than towers and airplanes fell on 9/11—with them fell a story about the avant-garde that has long denied its roots, its continuing relevance, and its complex entwinement with racial, sexual, religious, and colonial power.

Mike Sell  

Mike Sell is Associate Professor of English at Indiana University of Pennsylvania. He is the author of The Avant-Garde: Race Religion War (Seagull Books, forthcoming) and Avant-Garde Performance and the Limits of Criticism: Approaching the Living Theatre, Fluxus/Happenings, and the Black Arts Movement (U of Michigan, 2005) and editor of Avant-Garde Performance and Material Exchange: Vectors of the Radical (Palgrave Macmillan 2010) and Ed Bullins: Twelve Plays and Selected Writings (U of Michigan, 2006).

Project MUSE Journals Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011 Messianic Pains. The Apocalyptic Temporality in Avant-Garde Art, Politics, and War

Volume 18, Number 2, April 2011

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

Messianic Pains. The Apocalyptic Temporality in Avant-Garde Art, Politics, and War
Maria Stavrinaki

Once one has acquired the right ear and eye, one becomes restless, Franz Marc

Experienced by many artists as the era of private passions, devoid as such of the collective experiences necessary to the creation of "Great Art," modernity found more than once in war and revolution the propitious conditions for a salutary rupture. The majority of artists of the European avant-garde thus succumbed to the euphoria following the declaration of the First World War in 1914, in the hopes of living the powerful common experiences that the gloomy accumulation of days during peace time had seemed to deny them. Although they had previously defended their autonomy, transgressing without respite the limits defined by "tradition" and "common sense," those artists were now ready to recognize in war the "feast" of socialization, advocated once by Hegel as the necessary means for the taming of modern individualism.1 In other words, the war offered to the artist the opportunity to protect his self against its own excesses. Expecting to finish with the aporias inherent in the "autonomy of art," he desired to merge in the anonymity of the people.

It is widely acknowledged today that if the Great War accomplished this anonymity, it was in a radically different way than the one hoped for by artists: not simply interdependent, factories and armies became almost interchangeable in their means of production and in their ways of using workers and soldiers' labour power. Just as it was impossible for a worker to have a total vision of the industrial productive process, for individuals participating in battles it had become impossible to perceive the army's plan. The first deception that the war provoked in Max Beckmann was therefore the oppression of his individuality, which he had until then considered to be his most precious capital as an artist.2 In a manner similar to George Grosz, Ludwig Meidner, and Ludwig Kirchner, Beckmann would thereafter reject the industrial war for its capacity to multiply horror.3

Nevertheless, other artists' reactions to the war do not fall under the purview of such a disillusioned humanism. They were interested in the spirit or method of war rather than in its immediate effects. Despite their crucial differences, the Cubist Fernand Léger, the Expressionist Franz Marc, and the Italian Futurists belong to this general framework. No trace of the horror of war can be detected in their texts or war sketches: instead of focusing on the "inhuman" effects of the war, these artists paid attention to its capacity to abstract the human. Even though all of them recognized in the war's "methodological" abstraction the confirmation and objectification of their previous aesthetic battles, a clear distinction can be made between those who, like Léger, speculated about the war in a rationalist way, analyzing its principles and drawing appropriate conclusions for the future of their art, and those who, like Marc and the Futurists, lived the abstraction of the war in total empathy.4 This empathy, defined here as the subject's identification with the virtual object of its representation, produced ultimately the transration and, even, sacralization of the war. The war was sometimes sacralized in itself, as the climax of a transcendental experience, and sometimes as the means to accelerate the manifestation of the sacred.

At the beginning of the nineteenth century, the Romantic painter Philipp Otto Runge conceived his landscape painting (Landschafterey) as the anticipation of a new religion, purer and more abstract than Protestantism, which was itself already purer and more abstract than Catholicism; he momentarily imagined a war able to accelerate, by its purifying effects, the irruption of this new religion. Nonetheless, he soon confronted the tenacious inadequacy dividing modern forms of war and religion. In a letter to his brother Daniel written in 1802, the painter explains: "I once imagined a war able to turn the whole world upside down and the way that such a war could come, but since war was becoming a science everywhere in the world and no war was fair any more, I did not see any other means than the advent of the Last Judgment, when the earth will open to swallow up all of us."5 In Runge's view, the increasing rationalization of war was incompatible with any mystical effect. Secularized history could not assume the eschatological function that the artist still preferred to attribute to a transcendental Last Judgment, striking down human beings from above. One century later, however, it became clear to the sociologist Max Weber that war was the only situation where the bureaucratic State, ordinarily accomplishing its tasks in an impersonal and impassive way, could challenge religious ethics. In giving a meaning to what was strictly arbitrary, death itself, war was able to rouse in nations the spirit of sacrifice that only religious vocations or experiences of communion with God had been able to produce until then.6 This thesis would be confirmed by the Great War, whose mystical character was praised—at least during its first months—by many intellectuals and artists. Roger Caillois analyzes this phenomenon in several essays and, especially, in his book entitled Bellone ou la pente de la guerre. In contrast to Runge, Caillois insists on the infallible symmetry between modern war's emancipation of the human, resulting from its radical rationalization, and its increasing sacralization: "Nothing can be felt as sacred", he writes, "that cannot appear to man as completely alien to his own nature."7

The essential inhumanity of the sacred to which Caillois refers was valid in regard to the avant-gardes, who justified their formal abstractions before the war as the only expressive means appropriate to reveal the divine. The avant-gardes in Germany and Italy were ideologically prepared both to sacralize and aestheticize the First World War8. The fact that the war experience of numerous artists was characterized by an exact equivalence between the aesthetic and the sacred was due to the common apocalyptic structure of these two aspects, so much so that it is impossible to grasp the logic of the mystical war without considering the re of the "Apocalypse." The notion of "Apocalypse" corresponds to a polyvalent metaphor; it is a complex construction, interlocking aesthetics, politics and religiosity, the subjective and voluntarist quest for religion in modern times. Since this notion determined artistic ideologies before the war, the avant-gardes were ready to invest in the idea of an "apocalyptic war," a conceptual conjunction that had seemed so terribly incongruous a century before to the Romantic painter Philipp Otto Runge.

Declining the Metaphor of Nature

For the avant-gardes, war had started before the war. Despite the crucial differences among the several avant-garde trends, their common target was nature or reality: during the five years prior to the outbreak of the war, their discourse presented nature under several facets, all of which were interdependent. Material and passive, devoid as such of any original productive spirit, nature was above all a "woman."9 "Nature" included globally the concept of "accumulation": the accumulation of natural formations—natura naturata—or of fabricated objects, issued from the continuous production of capitalism. Nonetheless, accumulation also referred to the addition of artistic forms of the past. In this case, it denoted tradition and, to a greater extent, its parody: eclecticism. The influential anarchist essayist Ludwig Rubiner, for instance, an ethical and political model for Hans Pfemfert, the editor of the journal Die Aktion, asserts that "capitalism is not simply a state; it is an attitude. The exploitation of everything that exists in the world and that does not come from ourselves. In art, this attitude is hidden behind the concepts of 'tradition' and 'style'."10 From a temporal point of view, the avant-gardes rejected the mere accumulation of moments or events, in which they recognized linear, mechanical time. They also abhorred cyclical time, inscribed in daily labour as well as in the implacable repetition of the manifestations of nature. In regard to the past, accumulation as a macro-temporality signified historicism, and in regard to the future it signified blind, automatic evolutionism.

From a political point of view, the avant-gardes, from Kandinsky to the Futurists and the Expressionist Activists, were most often defiant of and even hostile to democratic representation, social democracy, and Marxist materialism. While parliaments had removed from the historical subject its capacity for direct action and produced what was only an apparent democracy, social democracy cancelled out the notion of revolution by transforming it into an evolutionist reformism. For the majority of artists, parliamentary democracy and social democracy corresponded to a kind of "political mimesis": they were limited to the political reproduction of the already existing. A social-democratic adept was thus ultimately the political equivalent of a Naturalist painter. One of the most striking expressions of this equivalence between art and politics was given by the activist Literat Kurt Hiller. Speaking in indistinct terms borrowed from artistic imitation and parliamentary democracy, these "sheer descriptions" as he qualified them,11 Hiller affirms: "Description is nothing; the elaboration of norms (Normation) is everything; we want to change, improve, help. We do not think nor feel psychologically; we think and feel politically."12

Marxist materialism was rejected for its determinism, disqualified as a product of scientific rationalism simply transferred from the field of natural sciences to the field of history. Moreover, the avant-gardes had a mediocre idea of the proletariat: its materialism seemed to them symmetrical to the materialism of the bourgeoisie. All in all, these facets of the real—spatial and temporal, aesthetic and political—were founded on the naive conviction that nature, reality, or the milieu was capable of engendering its own change. Nevertheless, as Kurt Pinthus claims, they could only achieve their mere reproduction. The editor of the well-known Expressionist anthology Menschendämmerung (Twilight of Humanity) , affirms after the end of the war: "Man calls reality (Wirklichkeit everything that exists outside him, around him and before him. He takes as 'real reality' nature and its manifestations [ … ]. He takes as reality the human past, History, whose he considers to be the last link. He takes as reality all the constellations and arrangements that he has created (State, economy, social order) so that he can be relieved of the burden of life."13 According to Pinthus, however, "Man can only be saved by man, and not by his environment."14 This is the reason why the avant-gardes had decided to produce a new aesthetic, historical, and political reality by means of what seemed to them to be their exclusive instrument, namely the spirit.

A Typology of the Apocalyptic Model: Rupture/Interval, Action/Waiting

In the book he dedicated in 1922 to the Anabaptist Thomas Münzer, the philosopher Ernst Bloch asserts that "the apocalyptic irruption shatters the over-abundance of history."15 Many artists and writers' investment in the re of the Apocalypse was due to its radical rupture of a time saturated by history, as well as to the dialectics of catastrophe and utopia inherent in the Apocalypse since the days of Jewish messianism.16 The Apocalypse of the artists was one of the res of modernity's secularization process. Its catastrophic and utopian action was supposed to emanate from subjectivity. The radical subjectivism of the avant-gardes was founded on the idea of an"interiority," either individual or collective, capable of applying its law to exterior reality. Despite the fact that the spiritualism and, more generally, the idealism of the avant-gardes blurred the boundaries between the political and the religious, one can hypothesize that their apocalyptic utopias became manifest globally in two major forms and according to two different temporalities: the Apocalypse with a social and political vocation, inspired by revolution and expected, as such, to take the form of a radical rupture; and the Apocalypse which maintained its religious vocation, conceived this time as a progressive revelation of a Geist, whose accomplishment would put an end to the materialist era. Apocalyptic revolution presupposed the voluntarist and activist attitude of the subject, while the "religious" apocalypse was indebted to the concept of "waiting": not for the Messiah, but for the ripening of time, for the realization of history's potential.

Political Ruptures

The analysis of Futurists and Expressionists' activist works and discourse outlines the type of apocalyptic revolution that they envisioned; mainly of anarchist origin, it is in other words opposed to parliamentarianism, social-democratic reformism, and Marxism. The critic Carl Einstein, for instance, an important member of the Expressionist circle around Die Aktion, did not indulge in the "democratic compromise," which constituted the main target of his text "Politische Anmerkungen" (Political notes) .17 He qualifies this compromise as "acrobatic," for it mainly consisted in the "neutralization" and the "dialectical resolution" of oppositions. To the re of the "dialectician" Einstein opposes the "univocal man" (eindeutig Mensch), ideally capable of combining "form and violence" (Form und Gewalt) in his "primitive" action. Parliamentary decrees are, according to Einstein, the illusory resolutions of conflicts, while he praises what he calls the "univocal" for its "unparliamentary" (unparlementarisch) character and its capacity to be "always identical to the construction of its Idea."18 Parliamentarianism's aesthetic corollary was, for the critic, the optical atomization, the indecision and passivity of Impressionist pictures. Einstein opposes the idea of a wilful art, capable of mastering the energy of the spirit by means of a solid form. In another text called simply "Das Gesetz" (The Law) , he describes the ideal process of both artistic and political action: the subject is expected to apply in both matters its own "Law," the "manifestation of transcendental formations" and of "powerful will." Law is autonomous and, as such, determined by a "real arbitrariness" (Willkür)19. This subjective arbitrariness should characterize both political and aesthetic action. Ludwig Rubiner goes to greater lengths to establish this equivalence between the artistic and the political: in praising the efficiency of the representational action of the poet and the painter, he makes them into the paradigmatic res of the activist man. Endowed with "Intensity" (Intensität)—a Bergsonian notion that the writer explains quite vaguely as "the conscious action of spirit"20 —artists are able to "transform inner images into facts"21 and to replace the actual forms of reality by "space (created) from within."22 In other words, there is no mediation, no qualitative transition between art and reality: plastic forms are converted into political actions, and reality is submitted to the formative power of the subject in the same way as the pictorial surface. The link between art and reality is "re-presentation": forms and actions are the exteriorizations or spatializations of subjective representations.

If Rubiner does not explain the concrete manner in which forms can be converted into actions, Italian Futurists do. Not simply equivalent or analogical, forms and actions have a rationalized and, more precisely, an instrumental relation. Umberto Boccioni, Luigi Russolo, and Carlo Carrà count on the action of the image's motor forces on the spectator: as a perceptive equivalent of the political realm, the suggestive image is at the same time its model and its instrument. The solidification of impressionist "ambivalence" by the "force-lines" and "force-forms" was a model for the organization of the amorphous masses during the Revolution.23 Russolo's painting Revolt (1911) comes naturally to mind when one reads the following lines from the manifesto "The Exhibitors to the Public" written in 1912: "With the desire to intensify the aesthetic emotions by blending, so to speak, the painted canvas with the soul of the spectator, we have declared that the latter, 'must in the future be placed in the center of the picture.' He shall not be present at, but participate in the action. If we paint the phases of a riot, the crowd battling with uplifted fists and the noisy onslaughts of cavalry are translated upon the canvas in sheaves of lines corresponding with all the conflicting forces, following the general law of violence of the picture. The force-lines must encircle and involve the spectator so that he will in a manner be forced to struggle himself with the persons in the picture."24

Still, the differences between the politically engaged Expressionists and the Futurists were at least as important as their commonalities. If the latter understood as literal the violence that the artistic form was supposed to tame in order better to propagate it, the Expressionists understood it in its ideal sense. One of the main influences on Futurism was exercised by the ideas of Georges Sorel on violence, while it was Piotr Kropotkin, Gustav Landauer, Erich Mühsam and other pacifist anarchists who determined the political conceptions of Die Aktion.25 In this regard, the nationalist bellicism of the Italian artists was the opposite of the cosmopolitan pacifism of the Germans. The latter, passably Christian in their majority, were also heavily influenced by Tolstoy, who, beyond his anarchistic convictions, also believed very firmly in the contagious character of art. Nevertheless, neither Tolstoy nor his German followers aspired to exploit the contagious capacities of art for the propagation of violence, but aimed at its elimination.26 In short, unlike the Sorelian revolution, the revolution of the Expressionist activists was pacifist, and, unlike the Marxist revolution, it was ideal.27

Despite their differences, all these different revolutions—the Sorelian, the Marxist, and the Expressionist—shared an apocalyptic character.28 The Expressionist revolution of the Idea in particular was supposed to emanate from the subject in an immediate, voluntary, and imperative way. One of the main themes in the political writings of Die Aktion is the rejection of the passive, messianic expectation. Carl Einstein ironically deplores the fact that liberal democracy succeeded in rationalizing even "catastrophes," and Ludwig Rubiner explains that the main element that differentiates "Spirit" from Zivilisation is its imperviousness to any kind of evolutionism. Spirit's ontological regime is exclusively "catastrophic." "Ideas are always there, and they are always new," Rubiner argues: "And every Idea is a catastrophe."29

As to Futurists, their reaction was similar to that of other anarcho-syndicalists in Italy. Zeev Sternhell has explained more than once the ways in which the anti-materialist and anti-rationalist revision of Marxism in Europe was able to attribute to the war the function they formerly attributed to revolution.30 From 1910 on, Marinetti and Boccioni progressively adopted the revolutionary nationalism of the journal La Lupa.31 Since the revolution was "moral" in its intentions, and certainly not economic, the war turned out to be the ideal baptismal field for the moulding of virtues such as courage, the ascetic renouncement of one's self, and so forth. In his book Guerrapittura, conceived and published during the war, Carlo Carrà writes: "War or revolution, both purifying, both invigorating."32 Later, when Futurism became one of the main components of fascism, Marinetti evokes very simply the "revolutionary war," guided by "a minority of intellectuals." "They were the best, the least imbued by tradition, the most Futurist. While the whole population was still immersed in the inertia of pacifism, they understood the need for the war."33

Religious Interval: Between the "Already" and the "Not Yet"

The works and essays of the artists who associated their activity with the destiny of religion put forward the idea of the Apocalypse as a progressive, secular Revelatio of the Spirit. Politics as such was not so important in the case of Vassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc; for them, the dystopias of their time were essentially a matter of religious defectiveness.34 It was this defectiveness that was about to end: "Today art is moving in a direction toward which our fathers would never even have dreamed. One stands before the new works as in a dream and hears the horsemen of the Apocalypse in the air. An artistic tension is felt all over Europe. Everywhere new artists are greeting each other."35 In the prospectus of the Almanach of the Blaue Reiter, authored by Marc, geographical universalism becomes a translation of historical determinism. In being an expression of History's will, new painting even draws its legitimizing metaphors from "nature": as Marc argues, new art crosses the borders of nations in the same arbitrary and thus undeniably objective way that grains are spread by the wind.36 His painting's universalism is as strong as the implacable determinism of natural laws: this is the sole positive reference to "blind" nature that Franz Marc allows himself. In any case, the historical identity of the era is one of tension between the materialism that was coming to an end and the progressive revelation of the "Great Spiritual." Artistic tension, of which the Almanach is a testimony in itself, was the anticipatory and condensed manifestation of this more global, but still latent, historical tension. The attitudes of Marc and Kandinsky towards history comprised waiting, interval, and distance: they believed the apocalyptic "revelation" to be progressive and immanent in history, even if they thought that they accelerated its realization by their works. They were living already what was not there yet: the incarnation of the spiritual in art reproduced, in short, the tensions and contradictions of the dogma of the Incarnation of God in Christ. Karl Löwith formulates this tension very subtly: "The times are already accomplished, but they are not completed yet. The time which separates the Resurrection of Christ from his Return is irrevocably the last one; but it is also, as long as it lasts, the last but one time which precedes the accomplishment of the kingdom of Christ, present but still secret, in the form of the manifested kingdom of the Father."37

The Antilogical Principle: From the Apocalyptic Istoria to the Apocalyptic Form

The Expressionist logic was grounded in the concept of a more or less radical "dissociation" between external and internal reality, matter and spirit, or the organic and the abstract. Like all the painters who worked on abstraction, Vassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc exhausted the consequences of the idea according to which nature's truth was hidden behind its appearances: the further pictorial forms were from the forms of nature, the better painting revealed the latter's (abstract) essence. Logical contradiction prevailed here: the more two objects seemed dissimilar, the more they were in fact similar. In the first letter he addressed to the composer Arnold Schönberg in January 18, 1911, Kandinsky qualifies his artistic conception as "antilogical." Elsewhere, in a great number of his essays, he raises "dissonance" to the level of the central notion of the pictorial and musical composition.38 Contrast, contradiction, antilogical, dissonance: all these notions are susceptible to being joined in the concept of the "Apocalypse." Expressionist aesthetics can thus be interpreted as an entirely apocalyptic aesthetics, and the conception of abstraction as "Revelation" (Ent-hüllung) of the hidden is not the sole reason for this equation.

It is widely known that in the years during which Kandinsky elaborated on abstraction, he was also obsessed with the themes of the Apocalypse and the Last Judgement. An important change took place in his paintings during those years: Apocalypse passed progressively from the status of istoria to that of form.39 Kandinsky's apocalyptic "feeling" was progressively interiorized by and assimilated into the "hidden construction" of forms and colors. The historical tension of the times was translated into the contrasting relations among plastic elements and it was spatialized in the tense convexity of space common in Expressionist paintings.40

The vertical size of The Last Judgment, a painting of 1910, is rather uncommon in the artist's production; the Apocalypse is signified here by a big trumpet, cutting the composition diagonally, but also by the citadel on the top of the "triangle," evoking the celestial Jerusalem and the Merezkovskian Moscow as the Third Rome.41 Through their strictly iconological character, these attributes construct the apocalyptic istoria. At the same time, however, they are completed in their action by the signifying function of the formal elements themselves, which are considerably dissociated from their objective referent. More precisely, the dissonant sounds of the trumpet are not only suggested by the kneeling re putting her fingers over her ears, but also by the highly contrasting colours and, above all, by the vibrating, trembling, and shaken space. This tense space, whose center is about to blow up, looks as if it was shaken by the shrill sounds of the apocalyptic trumpet. At the same time, the spots of colour express by their dilated and dissolving character the dematerialization and evaporation of sounds in the air. Ultimately, the de-objectification of the plastic elements signifies the de-objectification of the world that the Apocalypse is supposed to initiate. Not only does colour overflow the outline of objects, but the pictorial surface is also stretched like skin, or rather like a woman's belly hiding a new life. A double and apparently contradictory, gendered conception of the work of art determines Kandinsky's thought: the feminine function of pregnancy and the masculine function of the spectator's fertilization. In his Spiritual in Art, the artist affirms: "The art which does not enclose in itself any future potential and which is thus a child of its times will never engender the future: it is a castrated art."42 In spite of this, the ambivalent gender of Kandinsky's paintings was not contradictory: conceived either as a pregnant woman or as a generating male, its target was in both cases the spiritual fertilization of the spectator. In a similar way to the process of "imitatio Christi," the spectator was expected to interiorize the "apocalyptic" image and operate his own "revelation."
